The armed group claimed they are carrying out military operations to gain territory against the ELN.

Non-violent activity: Around 12 August 2021 (between 12 August - 13 August), in the rural area of Medio San Juan municipality (coded to Andagoya, Choco), Gulf Clan members interrogated several civilians in the rural communities of Union, Dipurdu, and Guasimo. The armed men marked the houses and subsequently fled the area. The area is known for an ongoing turf war between Gulf Clan members and the ELN.

ACTOR1: FARC Dissident - 37th Front: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia Dissident Faction (37th Front)
NOTES: Property destruction: On 12 August 2021, in the rural area of Simiti municipality, Bolivar, a 37th FARC front dissident threatened a private driver with a gun, took him to a private house, and set fire to the vehicle with other members of the armed group in La Y sector. ELN and FARC dissidents have been clashing in the zone.

Mass grave: Around 12 August 2021 (as reported), in the rural area of Ovejas municipality, Sucre, the Search Unit for Missing Persons (UBPD) of the Colombian government found 19 graves in the Montes de Maria mountain. The graves are likely related to forced recruitment or explosions, common during the armed conflict that took place in 1980s and 2000s in the area.

SOURCE: El Colombiano; El Universal (Colombia); Vanguardia Liberal; El Espectador
NOTES: Displacement: Around 14 August 2021 (weekend of), in the rural area of Andagoya municipality, Choco, at least 1.150 people were displaced in fear towards San Miguel, Isla de Cruz and the urban area. The displacement was caused due to clashes between Gulf Clan (AGC) and ELN in local corregimientos. At least 1,000 people were confined after Gulf Clan entered San Miguel corregimiento and La Union and left graffiti on the walls.

SOURCE: Comision Intereclesial de Justicia y Paz
NOTES: Displacement: Around 14 August 2021, in the rural area of Litoral del San Juan municipality (Choco), 197 Wounaan indigenous people were displaced from the areas of Union San Juan and Puerto Guadualito due to armed activity of Gulf Clan members who arrived at their area on 11 August 2021.

Property destruction: On 15 August 2021, in the rural area of Rio de Oro municipality, Cesar, four suspected armed members of EPL stopped a bus, ordered the passengers and the driver to get off and set fire to it on the road from Ocana to Aguas Claras. The bus belonged to the Copetran company.

Around 16 August 2021 (as reported), in El Paso, Cesar, police forces arrested the leader of the Manuel Jose Gaitan substructure of Gulf Clan (AGC). He was known for ordering the payment of extortion fees in the area.

Displacement: On 20 August 2021, in the rural area of Payan municipality, Narino, about 400 families were displaced from several veredas towards the urban area. They were displaced due to armed clashes between Gulf Clan (AGC), 30th FARC Front of dissidents and Oliver Sinisterra in the area.

Property destruction: Around 21 August 2021 (as reported), in a rural area of El Carmen (Norte de Santander), military forces found and destroyed a drug laboratory that belonged to the Camilo Torres ELN front. Security forces seized equipment and supplies used to process nearly 2 tons of cocaine each month.

Security measures: Around 23 August 2021, in San Faustino (Norte de Santander), residents of the corregimiento reported the presence of several ELN members. The report claimed the armed group carries out identity controls and other security measures among local residents.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Venezuela (1999-) GNB: Venezuelan National Guard
NOTES: Security measures: On 24 August 2021, in the area of Rio negro in the Guainia department (coded to Inirida), Colombian authorities reported that two members of the GNB of Venezuela carried out identity controls in Colombian territory. According to the report, the military officers invaded a Colombian ship anchored on the Colombian side of the border and intimidated the crew.

ACTOR1: FARC Dissident - Carolina Ramirez Front: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia Dissident Faction (Carolina Ramirez Front)
SOURCE: Comision Intereclesial de Justicia y Paz
NOTES: Movement of forces: Around 26 August 2021 (as reported), in Pinuna Negro, Puerto Leguizamo (Putumayo), residents have reported the increasing presence of armed men members of the Carolina Ramirez FARC dissident front. According to the communities, the armed men have harassed several members of the community.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Government of Colombia (2018-); FC: Citizen Force
NOTES: Other: Around 26 August 2021, the governor of the department of Magdalena (coded to Santa Marta), reported that he recently fled the country after a close source informed him that there was an execution plan to kill him by Gulf Clan members. The politician is a well-known activist and member of the CF left-wing political party.. The politician is a well-known activist and member of the leftist political party CF. Following the report, the armed group issued a public statement denying the governor's version.

SOURCE: Comision Intereclesial de Justicia y Paz
NOTES: Movement of forces: Around 30 August 2021 (as reported), in the rural area of Litoral del San Juan (Choco), Gulf Clan troops arrived in the region. Wounaan indigenous people from the Pichima Quebrada indigenous reserve area reported their arrival. Reports claimed the armed men area preparing a military offensive against ELN members.

Looting: On 30 August 2021, in the rural area of Saravena (Arauca), unidentified armed individuals stole the vehicle of the Unit for the Search for Missing Persons (UBPD). While a UBPD employee and a driver were driving through the municipality of Saravena, Arauca, armed individuals approached them and demanded that they hand over the vehicle. The area is known for the presence of armed groups.

ACTOR1: FARC Dissident - 28th Front: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia Dissident Faction (28th Front - Jose Maria Cordoba)
NOTES: Non-violent activity: Around 30 August 2021, in Saravena (Arauca), members of the 28th FARC dissident faction released a video on social media platforms calling for authorities to arrest a group of indigenous people reportedly involved in a robbery. The armed men gave 48hrs time for the police to capture the suspects. Otherwise, they will carry out a social cleansing in the municipality.

Displacement: Around 30 August 2021 (as reported), in Buenaventura (Valle del Cauca), 100 residents of the La Playita neighborhood fled due to armed group activity. The region is known for the presence of armed groups and increasing reports of armed clashes in urban areas.

Looting: Around 30 August 2021, in Buenaventura (Valle del Cauca), unidentified armed individuals stopped a go-fast boat used for residents as public transport and stole the vehicle's motor. Some of the passengers jumped into the water to avoid an encounter with the armed men.

ACTOR2: FARC Dissident - Alfonso Cano Front: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia Dissident Faction (Alfonso Cano Front)
NOTES: Property destruction: Around 1 September 2021, on the northern shore of Narino (coded to Coast of Narino), security forces found and seized a submarine that carried with 1.8 tons of cocaine. The drug belonged to the Alfonso Cano FARC dissident front.

Displacement: On 2 September 2021, in the rural area of Lloro municipality (Choco), 204 people from the La Playa area fled, following death threats from Gulf Clan members. The families sought shelter in the municipal seat.

Movement of forces: Around 5 September 2021, in Puerto Lopez, El Bagre municipality (Antioquia), residents reported the presence of Gulf Clan members in the locality. Inhabitants fear that there will be confrontations since the area is known to be controlled by the ELN members. The situation has caused the confinement of more than 8 thousand inhabitants of the village, as the Gulf Clan carried out surveillance and territorial control in the urban area.

ACTOR2: FARC Dissident - Dagoberto Ramos: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia Dissident Faction (Dagoberto Ramos)
NOTES: Other: On 5 September 2021, in the rural area of Caldono (Cauca), members of the local Guardia Indigena captured several suspected members of the Dagoberto Ramos FARC dissident faction.

ACTOR2: FARC Dissident - 33rd Front: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia Dissident Faction (33rd Front)
NOTES: Property destruction: Around 6 September 2021 (as reported), in a rural area of Sardinata (Norte de Santander), military forces found and destroyed a drug laboratory that belonged to the FARC 33rd dissident front. Security forces seized 1,553 kilograms of cocaine and 55 kilograms in equipment and supplies used to process drugs.

ACTOR2: FARC Dissident - Jaime Martinez: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia Dissident Faction (Jaime Martinez)
NOTES: Weapons seizure: Around 7 September 2021 (as reported), in the rural area of Candelaria (Valle del Cauca), military forces found and seized 180 kilograms of explosives hidden in a sugarcane field. The Jaime Martinez FARC dissident faction planned to use the explosives to attack security forces in the municipalities of Pradera.

Displacement: On 8 September 2021, in Banco De Arenas, Cucuta municipality (Norte de Santander), more than 100 people fled the corregimiento, following death threats from unidentified armed individuals. The families sought shelter in the municipal seat. The region is known for the presence of armed groups and increasing reports of armed clashes in rural areas.

SOURCE: Comision Intereclesial de Justicia y Paz
NOTES: Property destruction: On 11 September 2021, in Pinuna Blanca, Puerto Asis (Guaviare), Nasa indigenous people reported that police forces broke into an indigenous territory and forcibly destroyed several coca crops. The civilians claimed that the officers threatened community members when they approached them to ask them not to damage the plants before reaching an agreement with the community.

LOCATION: Coast of San Andres y Providencia
NOTES: Property destruction: Around 11 September 2021, near the coast of San Andres y Providencia (San Andres y Providencia), military forces seized 2.4 tons of cocaine transported in a speedboat. The drugs belonged to the Gulf Clan. Five people were arrested in the operation.

SOURCE: El Colombiano; Vanguardia Liberal; El Tiempo (Colombia)
NOTES: Property destruction: On 12 September 2021, in the rural area of Barrancabermeja municipality (Santander), unidentified men planted and set off explosives near two different oil pipelines near the El Centro corregimiento, resulting in a massive oil spill and a wildfire. Authorities believe that the attack was perpetrated by members of the Gulf Clan as retaliation for the arrest of two of their members, while a second source claimed police connected the attack to ELN members.

Movement of forces: Around 13 September 2021 (as reported), in the Arauca department (coded to Arauca municipality), nearly 300 additional troops were deployed by military forces to carry out operations in the rural areas of the department against armed groups that operate in the region.

SOURCE: Comision Intereclesial de Justicia y Paz
NOTES: Security measures: On 14 September 2021, in the department of Antioquia (code to Murindo), the ELN distributed messages among the communities of Murindo, Dabeiba and Frontino restricting the movement of people in areas outside the marked roads. The armed group reported that they planted several landmines in the forested areas of the aforementioned municipalities.

ACTOR1: FARC Dissident - Mobile Column: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia Dissident Faction (Adan Izquierdo)
NOTES: Property destruction: On 16 September 2021, in the rural area of Tulua (Valle del Cauca), suspected members of the dissident FARC faction Adan Izquierdo set fire to two vehicles belonging to the local energy company. According to witnesses, four men on two motorcycles stopped the vehicles at Las Garzas and Venus veredas, asked the occupants to get off and proceeded to burn down the cars.

Property destruction: Around 19 September 2021 (as reported), in a rural area of Tibu (Norte de Santander), military forces found and destroyed a drug laboratory that belonged to the ELN. Security forces seized equipment and supplies used to process cocaine. Security forces found 3.3 tons of cocaine hydrochloride, more than 4,068 gallons of liquid supplies and 608 kilos of solid supplies.

SOURCE: Comision Intereclesial de Justicia y Paz
NOTES: Property destruction: Around 25 September 2021 (weekend of), in the rural area of Villagarzon municipality (Putumayo), Nasa indigenous people reported the destruction of several hectares of native forest within indigenous reserve zones. Residents claimed that armed groups deforested the area attempting to expand areas to plant coca plants.

SOURCE: Comision Intereclesial de Justicia y Paz
NOTES: Displacement: Around 25 September 2021 (as reported), in the rural area of Carmen del Darien (Choco), 12 Embera indigenous families were displaced from the Urada Jiguamiando indigenous reserve area due to armed group activity.

Property destruction: Around 27 September 2021 (as reported), on the Pacific coast area (coded to Coast of Narino), security forces found and seized a submarine that carried up to 3 tons of cocaine. The drug and vehicle belonged to the Gulf Clan. Three people were arrested and several weapons were seized in the operation.

ACTOR2: Military Forces of Venezuela (1999-) GNB: Venezuelan National Guard
NOTES: On 27 September 2021, in the rural area of La Parada corregimiento, Villa del Rosario municipality (Norte de Santander), police forces arrested two armed members of the Venezuelan GNB forces in the El Mango crossing. Although the men claimed they were off-duty at the moment of the arrests, security forces found several ammunition and weapons. The men were later released by a Colombian judge.

Displacement: Around 29 September 2021 (as reported), in the rural area of Dabeiba (Antioquia), nearly 1,000 Embera indigenous people were displaced from the Amparrado Alto y Medio, Canaverales, Amoladora, Genaturado, Antado Arena, and Antado Guavina indigenous reserve area due to armed group activity. Sources also reported that at least another 282 families have restrictions of movement after armed groups planted several landmines in the rural pathways.

Around 30 September 2021 (as reported), in the rural area of Buritica (Antioquia), military and police forces arrested 45 miners who worked for the Edwing Roman Gulf Clan front. The men carried out illegal mining activities in the Los Arados vereda. Security forces seized equipment used to excavate the mine.

Security measures: On 3 October 2021, in the rural area of Ovejas (Cordoba), two armed men who identified themselves as Gulf Clan members visited the house of 46 farmers in the Europa plot of land, telling people that Gulf Clan members would begin using the area for transporting drugs and other assets towards the Pacific Coast. Authorities arrested the two individuals after farmers reported the event to a local military unit.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: FARC Dissident - 10th Front: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia Dissident Faction (10th Front)
NOTES: Movement of forces: Around 4 October 2021 (as reported), in Puerto Rondon and Cravo Norte municipalities (coded to Puerto Rondon, Arauca), local human rights organizations denounced a growing movement of forces from members of the ELN and the 10th FARC dissident faction. According to the source, the armed groups are disputing control of these two municipalities, increasing the risk of armed clashes in the area.

Land seizure: Around 4 October 2021 (as reported), around Bogota (Bogota, D.C.), security forces seized several real state properties that would belong to the Gulf Clan. Nearly 20 buildings, 11 vehicles, 11 companies, four stores, and other assets, were found in Antioquia, Atlantico, Boyaca, Risaralda, Quindio, Meta, Vichada, and Bogota departments during the operation.

Non-violent activity: Around 4 October 2021, in the rural area of Palmor, Cienaga municipality (Magdalena), the conflict between two different Kogui indigenous clans in the Tucurinca vereda escalated as one of the groups restricted all movements from one of the clans. The group acted in retaliation after a recent event where one of the clans declared its independence from another group. Nearly 500 Kogui Indians are prohibited from moving freely in the area of the indigenous reserve.

Movement of forces: On 6 October 2021, in Norte de Santander department (coded to Cucuta), military forces deployed an additional 14,000 troops to guard the border with Venezuela. Government officials said the main task of the new unit is to combat members of armed groups operating in the area, such as the Gulf Clan, the ELN and dissident factions of the FARC.

Displacement: Around 7 October 2021 (as reported), in the rural area of the El Carmen De Atrato municipality (Choco), between 196 to 200 indigenous people were displaced due to armed group activity. The group fled to Medellin to search for a shelter after unidentified armed individuals threatened the communities.

Defusal: Around 9 October 2021 (weekend of), in the rural area of El Cerrito (Valle del Cauca), military forces defused four explosive devices planted by an unidentified group. Three explosives cylinders were located on the main road that connects El Cerrito and Rozo municipalities. The highway was closed for several hours due to the operation to defuse the device. A day later, police forces defused a fourth device hidden on the road that connects El Cerrito with Andalucia.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Former AUC: United Self-Defence Forces of Colombia
NOTES: Non-violent activity: Around 12 October 2021, in the Bolivar department (coded to Cartagena), six former members of the AUC were threatened by suspected Gulf Clan members following their participation in a local truth commission that investigates human rights violations, war crimes, or other serious abuses made by the former group.

ACTOR2: FARC Dissident - Ivan Rios: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia Dissident Faction (Ivan Rios Front)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: GUP: United Guerrillas of the Pacific
NOTES: Property destruction: Around 14 October 2021 (as reported), in a rural area of Tumaco municipality (Narino), military forces found and destroyed a drug laboratory in the Congal corregimiento that reportedly belonged to the Ivan Rios FARC dissident faction (Los Contadores) and the GUP. Security forces seized equipment and supplies used to process cocaine, including 2.065 kilograms of cocaine, 222 kilograms of coca base, 5.925 kilograms of solid supplies, among other equipment.

ACTOR1: FARC Dissident - 36th Front: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia Dissident Faction (36th Front - Jair Aldana Baquero)
NOTES: Non-violent activity: Around 15 October 2021 (month of), in the municipalities of Caceres, Anori, Amalfi, Zaragoza, and Taraza (coded to Caceres, Antioquia) members of the FARC 36th dissident faction distributed pamphlets demanding citizens to register at the local JAC. According to the report, the armed group is planning to create identification cards for each resident. Local leaders expressed their concerns that this action might lead to restriction of movement and targeting of local activists.

SOURCE: Comision Intereclesial de Justicia y Paz
NOTES: Movement of forces: On 18 October 2021, in the rural area of Litoral del San Juan (Choco), Gulf Clan troops arrived in the region, according to reports of inhabitants of the Isla Mono area. Reports claimed the armed men area preparing an operation against ELN members.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Government of Colombia (2018-); CR: Radical Change; Former Government of Colombia (2018-)
NOTES: On 20 October 2021, in Arauca department (coded to Arauca), police forces arrested the current governor of the department, who is a member of the CR political party, for alleged links to the ELN. Authorities claimed that the politician provided the armed group with several public contracts as payment to support his 2020 election campaign. Two days later after the first arrest, security forces also arrested in Bogota the former governor of the Arauca department under similar charges.

Property destruction: On 22 October 2021, in the rural area of Uribia (La Guajira), Wayuu indigenous militia from the Girnu clan set fire to the houses of Wayuu Indigenous people from a different clan in the Topia area. The group threatened the victims to leave the area and claimed land rights over the victim's land.

Other: On 23 October 2021, in the rural area of Uribia (La Guajira), about 30 Wayuu indigenous families from the Topia area were displaced to Riohacha due to threats from an indigenous Wayuu militia group. Perpetrators demanded that the families leave the area due to a land conflict.
On 23 October 2021, in the rural area of Turbo (Antioquia), military forces captured the leading member of the Gulf Clan during a military operation launched on 22 October.

Other: On 27 October 2021, in the El Carmen De Atrato municipality (Choco), members of the Indigenous Guard forced a unit of seven military soldiers and three police officers to interrupt their operations, alleging that their presence in the area increases the risk of armed confrontations, endangering the security of civilians in the region. Military sources claimed that the community held the soldiers captive for several days and that they were released by a humanitarian commission.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: JAC: Council of Communal Action; Unidentified Communal Group (Colombia)
NOTES: Other: Around 29 October 2021 (as reported), in Cucuta (Norte de Santander), social leaders and members of the Juntas de Accion Comunal (JAC) reported being harassed by unidentified individuals on motorcycles. Such incidents are reported on the eve of the election of new members of the local JAC. As a result, all JAC members in district 8 resigned from their positions for fear of attack.

Defusal: On 30 October 2021, in Banco De Arenas (Norte de Santander), military forces defused an explosive device planted by suspected ELN members in the Puerto Leon Bridge on 27 October. The armed group left a flag of the organization. Residents expressed their concern over the security of civilians as the explosive was left on the bridge for three days before authorities showed up to deactivate the device.

Property destruction: Around 1 November 2021 (as reported), in Turbo (Antioquia), military forces found and destroyed 3,8 tons of cocaine hidden in a container. According to local authorities, the cocaine belonged to the Gulf Clan.

Displacement: Around 2 November 2021, in the rural area of Argelia (Cauca), more than 1,000 students were displaced due to the activity of armed groups in the area. Likewise, at least 10 schools were forced to close or cancel all classes due to the presence of armed groups in the area.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: FARC Dissident - Second Marquetalia: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia Dissident Faction (Segunda Marquetalia)
NOTES: Non-violent activity: Around 5 November 2021 (as reported), in Argelia municipality (Cauca), the ELN and the Second Marquetalia FARC dissident faction threatened to burn all vehicles passing through the municipality during the day. The complaint was made by social leaders and inhabitants of the area. The armed group introduced a rule restricting movement among residents after a clash with a dissident faction of the FARC.

ACTOR2: FARC Dissident - 33rd Front: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia Dissident Faction (33rd Front)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Comunes Party; ASCAMCAT: Catatumbo's Peasant Association; JAC: Council of Communal Action; Farmers (Colombia)
NOTES: Arrest: On 7 November 2021, in the rural area of El Tarra (Norte de Santander), police forces arrested a suspected member of the 33rd FARC dissident faction who is accused of carrying out an attack against the presidential chopper on 25 June. According to authorities, the man used a vehicle of the UNP as he was registered as a member of the Comunes Political party and had run for councilman for this political party. Moreover, authorities claimed he was part of local JAC and other social organizations such as ASCAMCAT. The latter released a public statement denying the police version and claimed that is an effort from local authorities to discredit grass-root organizations.

Property destruction: Around 8 November 2021 (as reported), in Bijagual (Antioquia) , military officers destroyed machinery intended to be used for illegal mining. The machinery was the property of the Gulf Clan, who use illegal mining to finance their activities. 14 people were arrested.
Displacement: On 9 November 2021, in the rural area of Argelia (Cauca), at least 250 people were displaced due to the activity of armed groups in the area.

Mass grave: Around 9 November 2021 (as reported), in the rural area of El Castillo municipality (Meta), the Search Unit for Missing Persons (UBPD) of the Colombian government found 12 graves, likely related to civilians and members of armed groups killed during the armed conflict.

ACTOR2: FARC Dissident: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia Dissident Faction
NOTES: Defusal: Around 12 November 2021, in the rural area of Uribe (Meta), military forces deactivated an explosive device placed near a rural school in the La Paz vereda. Authorities stated that the explosive was planted by members of a dissident faction of the FARC.

ACTOR2: FARC Dissident: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia Dissident Faction
NOTES: Defusal: Around 12 November 2021, in the rural area of Uribe (Meta), military forces defused an explosive device planted by suspected FARC dissidents near a local school in the La Paz vereda.

Movement of forces: Around 18 November 2021, in Convencion (Norte de Santander), residents reported that ELN troops were patrolling the streets of the town's center. According to some of the store owners in the area, members of the armed group asked them for money, but no violent action was reported by the community. No confrontations were reported, despite the fact that there was a police station and a military unit nearby.

ACTOR1: FARC Dissident - Jorge Briceno Front: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia Dissident Faction (Jorge Briceno Front)
ACTOR2: Police Forces of Colombia (2018-) UNP: National Unit for Protection
NOTES: Property destruction: On 18 November 2021, in the rural area of San Vicente del Caguan municipality (Caqueta), unidentified armed individuals set fire to at least four vehicles of the UNP. The cars were assigned to protect former members of the FARC -EP who live in the area. Reports claimed that perpetrators also stole weapons and other equipment from the people who were driving the vehicles. Further investigations claimed the FARC dissident faction Jorge Briceno as responsible for the incident.

Property destruction: On 20 November 2021, in Turbo (Antioquia), unidentified individuals set fire to the houses of displaced families who had recovered their land through the land restitution program. The families were initially displaced by paramilitary groups and the area was subsequently sold to a well-known former politician. After a lawsuit, the farmers recovered the land in March 2020. The victims had required UNP police protection due to ongoing death threats. Although the perpetrators of the attack have not been confirmed, the area is known for the presence of the Gulf Clan. The building was empty when the attack occurred.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Refugees/IDPs (Colombia); Former FARC: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia
NOTES: Displacement: Around 21 November 2021 (as reported), in the rural area of La Macarena (Meta) 106 families and former FARC-EP members were displaced from the Urias Rondon ETCR vereda due to the activity of FARC dissident factions. Families decided to abandon the area following an incident in which suspected members of a FARC dissident faction set fire to several vehicles of the UNP who were assigned to residents of this locality.

Defusal: On 22 November 2021, in the rural area of Florida municipality (Valle del Cauca), police and military forces detonated in a controlled way 110 kilograms of explosives in the Chicosito vereda. Although authorities declared that the explosives belonged to the FARC dissident faction Dagoberto Ramos, the owner of the substance has not been confirmed. The area is known for the presence of armed groups.

SOURCE: Comision Intereclesial de Justicia y Paz
NOTES: Movement of forces: Around 22 November 2021 (as reported), in the rural area of Bajo Calima locality (Valle del Cauca), heavily armed men from the Gulf Clan arrived in the Santa Rosa de Guayacan Wounnan indigenous reserve area and the San Antonio del Guadual Afro-Colombian area. Residents claimed that the armed men patrolled the area, entered theirs houses, and stole a boat from a local resident. At least 50 Afro-Colombian families were displaced for fear of imminent clashes with other armed groups.

ACTOR2: FARC Dissident: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia Dissident Faction
NOTES: Property destruction: Around 22 November 2021, in a rural area of Francisco Pizarro municipality (coded to Salahonda, Narino), military forces found and destroyed a drug laboratory that belonged to a FARC dissident faction. Security forces seized equipment and supplies used to process cocaine, a speed boat and 1,555 kilograms of cocaine. Three people were arrested.

SOURCE: El Espectador; El Colombiano; El Tiempo (Colombia)
NOTES: Property destruction: On 23 November 2021, in a rural area of Samaniego municipality (Narino), military and police CTI forces found and destroyed two drug laboratories that belonged to the Jaime Tono Obando front of the ELN. Security forces seized equipment and supplies used to process cocaine and nearly 10 tons of cocaine ready to be shipped.

Property destruction: Around 23 November 2021, in the rural area of Rio Viejo municipality (Bolivar), military forces found and destroyed an illegal mining complex that belonged to the ELN. Officers seized 3 backhoes and other mining equipment use by the armed group.

Property destruction: On 25 November 2021, in La Tebaida (Quindio), two unidentified individuals who arrived on a motorcycle set to fire the house of the local government secretary. The house was empty at the moment of the attack. There was some damage to the front of the house, but the flames did not reach its interior.

SOURCE: Comision Intereclesial de Justicia y Paz
NOTES: Property destruction: On 25 November 2021, in the rural area of Puerto Caicedo (Putumayo), military forces broke into a Nasa indigenous territory in the Alpes Orientales indigenous reserve area and forcibly destroyed several coca crops. The civilians claimed that the officers threatened community members when they approached them to ask them not to damage the plants before reaching an agreement with the community.

ACTOR2: FARC Dissident - 30th Front: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia Dissident Faction (30th Front)
NOTES: Property destruction: Around 27 November 2021, in the rural area of Timbiqui (Cauca), the military forces found and destroyed a warehouse with several supplies belonging to the dissident faction 30 of the FARC near the Boca de Patia vereda. The material included 10 sewing machines and equipment, 750 meters of camouflage cloth, 1 ton of food supplies, and 50 kilograms of explosive material.

Elections/referendum: On 28 November 2021, nationwide (coded to Bogota, Bogota, D.C.), elections of the new members of the Council of Communal Action (JAC) were held. The initial date, scheduled for April, was postponed due to the coronavirus pandemic. Local organizations expressed concerns about the disruption of the electoral process by armed groups, particularly in the department of Antioquia.

SOURCE: Comision Intereclesial de Justicia y Paz
NOTES: Property destruction: On 29 November 2021, in the rural area of Puerto Guzman (Putumayo), nearly 20 members of the military forces broke into a Nasa indigenous territory in the El Descanso indigenous reserve area and forcibly destroyed several coca crops. The civilians claimed that the officers threatened community members when they approached them to ask them not to damage the crops before reaching an agreement with the community.

ACTOR1: FARC Dissident - Second Marquetalia: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia Dissident Faction (Segunda Marquetalia)
NOTES: Change to armed group: Around 29 November 2021, in the departments of Caqueta, Meta, Guaviare, Vichada, and Guainia (coded to Florencia, Caqueta), FARC dissidents of the Second Marquetalia and CDF forces allied in order to fight over the control of the territories against the Gentil Duarte FARC dissident group.

Movement of forces: On 1 December 2021, in the Caribbean coast (coded to Yarumal, Antioquia) Gulf Clan activity was reported in several locations, including the Mina Vieja area (Yarumal municipality), Monte Verde area (Taraza municipality), and Olimpica (Caucasia municipality). Stretches of the road that connects the center of the country with the Caribbean coast were blocked by authorities due to the presence of the group.

ACTOR1: FARC Dissident - Carlos Patino Front: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia Dissident Faction (Carlos Patino Front)
NOTES: Property destruction: On 2 December 2021, in the rural area of Balboa municipality (Cauca), suspected members of the FARC dissident faction Carlos Patino set fire to two tanker trucks loaded with gasoline in the San Alfonso area. The perpetrators intercepted the vehicles on the road between Balboa and Argelia, forced the drivers to get out and then burned the cars.

ACTOR1: FARC Dissident - Carlos Patino Front: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia Dissident Faction (Carlos Patino Front)
NOTES: Security measures: On 4 December 2021, in the municipality of Argelia (Cauca), suspected members of the FARC dissident faction Carlos Patino introduced curfew measures, prohibiting vehicles from traveling across the municipality. The incident followed an attack around 2 December in which suspected members of the group set fire to two tank trucks loaded with gasoline in the San Alfonso area. About 20,000 farmers have been affected by the traffic restriction and some vehicles were parked across the roads to block traffic.

ACTOR1: FARC Dissident - Second Marquetalia: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia Dissident Faction (Segunda Marquetalia)
NOTES: Security measures: On 6 December 2021, in the rural localities of the El Tambo municipality (Cauca), members of the FARC dissident faction Second Marquetalia and ELN distributed pamphlets across the town declaring the beginning of a curfew. The armed groups claimed all vehicles and civilians are prohibited to travel in the towns of Playa Rica, Huisito, La Paloma, Las Palmas, Pandiguando, and Honduras.

Change to armed group: Around 7 December 2021 (as reported), in the rural area of Cucuta municipality (Norte de Santander), remaining members of the Los Rastrojos who operated in the rural areas of the city joined the Gulf Clan, following a turf war between both armed groups.

Property destruction: Around 9 December 2021 (as reported), in a rural area of Tumaco municipality (Narino), military forces destroyed 14 drug laboratories in the areas of Mejicano, Rosario, Chagui, and Mira, where armed groups are known to engage in drug production activities. Security forces seized equipment and supplies used to process more than 12 tons of cocaine. 4 people were arrested.

On 29 May 2018, police officers seized 166 packages of cocaine weighing approximately 1.5-2.5 kilograms each in Los Angeles of Grecia in Alajuela. The drug belonged to a group linked to El Chapo cartel (Sinaloa) in Mexico. It is reported that four cars were also seized. Six Mexicans and one Guatemalan were arrested.

Between January 1 and 2 2019, in Costa Rica, 200 people arrived from Nicaragua to ask for asylum. It is reported that Nicaraguans have crossed the border to go into exile in Costa Rica due to the level of repression of Daniel Ortega's regime.

On Jan 30 2019, police and immigration authorities entered the Crucitas mine in San Carlos, province of Alajuela to evict dozens of artisanal miners accused of causing serious environmental damage in the area by using mercury to extract gold.

Reported on 24 July 2019, the Judicial Investigation Department confirmed the capture and arrest of Venezuelan Ex-governor Eduardo Manuitt Carpio for counts of blocking freedom, threats, coercion and torture. His brother and son were also detained.

On 30 July 2019 in several sectors of Alajuela, police forces launched 36-operations simultaneously in the Zona Sur, Zona Norte and Desamparados neighborhoods which resulted in the arrests of 42 people tied with human trafficking.

SOURCE: La Prensa Libre (Costa Rica); AFP; La Nacion (Costa Rica)
NOTES: On 30 July 2019 in La Cruz (Guanacaste), a joint operation between the police forces of Costa Rica and Panama resulted in the arrest of 46 people (36 in Costa Rica and 10 in Panama) and the dismantling of a migrant trafficking gang. Among the arrested there were citizens from Nicaragua.

On August 12 2019, officers of the Judicial Investigation Agency (OIJ) and the Special Intervention Unit (UEI) found three explosives in the Legislative Assembly in San Jose. It is reported that the explosives had no device to detonate. No further specifications.

On August 15 2019, police officers arrested 28 people in San Jose due to their irregular immigration situation in the country. It is reported that police officers visited several shops and nightclubs to capture these individuals.

Between August 23 and 27 2019, near the Crucitas mine in San Carlos, Alajuela, police officers arrested 135 individuals of Nicaraguan nationality. The individuals were reported to be in an irregular immigration situation and had tools and equipment to practice illegal mining. It is also reported that police officials have seized mining sediment, processed gold, and stopped illegal logging activities in the area.
On September 5 2019, at the Legislative Assembly in San Jose, there was a bomb threat. It is reported that a man with a briefcase would detonate an explosive in the Assembly building.
On 13 March 2020 in Limon (Limon) the Court of Justice was evacuated due to a bomb threat. It is unclear whether a bomb was effectively found at the court building. No one was injured nor dead.

On 18 March 2020, Costa Rica declared the coronavirus pandemic a national emergency and closed all borders. Furthermore, incoming travelers need to ovbserve a 14-day quarantine. On 23 March 2020, the government also established it will withdraw the residency permit to everyone leaving Costa Rica during the national emergency, in an effort to contain travels, especially from Costa Rica to Nicaragua during the Christian holiday of Holy Week.

As reported on 10 April 2020, in Las Tablillas (Alajuela), authorities in Costa Rica installed an airport base and increased the number of police forces to control its border with Nicaragua, due to inaction of the Nicaraguan government in response to the spread of the new coronavirus.

Other: On 15 April 2021, in Cabagra municipality, Puntarenas, a group of eight men threatened Bribri indigenous families with death while shooting into the air in the sector La Junta. The threats come after Bribri members have recuperated their territory known as Quebrada de Armadillos. The indigenous requested police presence in the region to guarantee the community's safety.
On 4 June 2021, close to El Tejar, Cartago, police officers arrested 69 migrants, 9 of whom are minors, on the South Interamerican highway.

Security measures: On 1 October 2021, in San Jose, San Jose, the government extended coronavirus restrictions through at least 15 October. These restrictions include a nightly ban on movement of vehicles and business operations unless justified between 10 pm and 5 am. International travel restrictions remain unchanged.
On 6 October 2021, in an undisclosed location (coded to San Jose), San Jose, police officers found and arrested 40 Haitian migrants travelling illegally in a bus.

On 15 November 2021, in Alajuela, Alajuela, police forces arrested the municipality's Mayor on charges of corruption during the municipal procurement processes. According to the report, the operation nicknamed 'Diamante' involved 40 raids in municipalities across the country and totaled 11 arrests until 15 November. Five of the arrested are municipal mayors who were suspended from their positions but were released from prison on 17 November 2021 after the public ministry did not request preventative detention before the court hearings.

On 15 November 2021, in Muelle San Carlos, Alajuela, police forces arrested the municipality's Mayor on charges of corruption during the municipal procurement processes. According to the report, the operation nicknamed 'Diamante' involved 40 raids in municipalities across the country and totaled 11 arrests until 15 November. Five of the arrested are municipal mayors who were suspended from their positions but were released from prison on 17 November 2021 after the public ministry did not request preventative detention before the court hearings.

On 15 November 2021, in Cartago, Cartago, police forces arrested the municipality's Mayor on charges of corruption during the municipal procurement processes. According to the report, the operation nicknamed 'Diamante' involved 40 raids in municipalities across the country and totaled 11 arrests until 15 November. 5 of the arrested are municipal mayors who were suspended from their positions but were released from prison on 17 November 2021 after the public ministry did not request preventative detention before the court hearings.

On 15 November 2021, near Sierpe, Puntarenas, police forces arrested the municipality's Mayor on charges of corruption during the municipal procurement processes. According to the report, the operation nicknamed 'Diamante' involved 40 raids in municipalities across the country and totaled 11 arrests until 15 November. Five of the arrested are municipal mayors who were suspended from their positions but were released from prison on 17 November 2021 after the public ministry did not request preventative detention before the court hearings.

On 15 November 2021, in San Jose, San Jose, police forces arrested the capital's Mayor on charges of corruption during the municipal procurement processes. According to the report, the operation nicknamed 'Diamante' involved 40 raids in municipalities across the country and totaled 11 arrests until 15 November. Five of the arrested are municipal mayors who were suspended from their positions but were released from prison on 17 November 2021 after the public ministry did not request preventative detention before the court hearings.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: FAC-OZT: Civic Action Front Orlando Zapata Tamayo; Women (Cuba)
NOTES: Around 10 February 2018 (between 5 and 16 February), in Habana city, a total number of 45 female human rights activists and Civic Action Front Orlando Zapata Tamayo (FAC-OZT) members were arrested by the police on 5, 9 and 16 February as they were on their way to a commemoration mass organized by the opposition group Ladies in White. The activists were released hours later in different areas of La Habana.

On 8 April 2018, in Habana city, the leader of the movement Ladies in White, 10 members of the movement and another man where arrested in a police operation in front of the main offices of the movement. 12 arrests in total.
On 22 June 2018, the residence of the wife of a political prisoner was vandalized in Placetas by a group allegedly associated with the Cuban government.
On 3 August 2018, Jose Daniel Ferrer, leader of the Union Patriotica de Cuba, opposition party, was arrested in Santiago de Cuba, Cuba.
Between 30 Nov and 3 Dec, the Cuban Police deployed operations in front of the houses of different HE and pro-democratic activist in La Habana.

On September 7, in Santiago de Cuba, a group of soldiers entered the offices of the opposition group UNPACU and detained 26 people, UNPACU says in a violent manner, and that soldiers stole food from them.

On October 1, 2019, in Santiago de Cuba, the leader of the opposition movement UNPACU was detained and imprisoned, his family saw him in prison on October 3rd but he has not been seen again as of October 31st.
On 20 March 2020, the borders of Cuba were closed to everyone but nationals of Cuba to prevent the spread of coronavirus.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Lawyers (Cuba); UNPACU: Patriotic Union of Cuba
NOTES: On 21 June 2020, in Habana, the house of a former prosecutor who joined the UNPACU opposition group was raided by police. The officers broke the phone of his wife and confiscated a number of items. The man was detained without charge and kept in a room for seven hours before being released.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Ladies in White; Women (Cuba); Journalists (Cuba); Labour Group (Cuba); UNPACU: Patriotic Union of Cuba
NOTES: On 30 June 2020, in Cuba, a number of prominent activists and opposition members, such as the national coordinator of the CIR and two performance artists, members of the Ladies in White, the San Isidro movement, journalists and UNPACU members, were arrested or put under house arrest across the country in order to prevent a protest against the killing of a man by the police. A week before, a man was shot by the police allegedly for not wearing a face mask and for throwing stones at the police. A total of 84 people were ordered to stay home, and 52 people were arrested.

Property destruction: On 6 September 2020, in Santiago de las Vegas, La Habana, members of the Communist Party of Cuba vandalized the facade of a house on which there was a writing against the Castro regime.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: MONR: Opposition Movement for a New Republic; UNPACU: Patriotic Union of Cuba; Ladies in White; Journalists (Cuba)
NOTES: On 8 September 2020, in Habana, Habana, and elsewhere on Cuba, police suppressed a planned protest over the Sunflower Revolution. Over 80 people of various opposition movements including MONR, UNPACU and Ladies in White as well as journalists and artists were arrested by the police. The leaders of the UNPACU and Ladies in White were also arrested.
On 26 September 2020, in Holguin, Holguin, police officers who were drunk entered a house, broke belongings and set fire to the kitchen. The resident started a hunger strike following the incident.

On 13 November 2020, in Habana, Habana, police cracked down on the opposition group San Isidro Movement by arresting a number of prominent activists who were planning to protest against the detention of one of their activists.

On 22 November 2020, in Habana, Habana, two Ladies in White, including the leader of the movement, were arrested by state forces when they were trying to reach the San Isidro neighborhood to support the San Isidro Movement. In another location in the Matanzas province, two Ladies in White were also arrested when trying to get to the central park to stage a protest. In the city of Colon five people were arrested.

On 28 November 2020, in Habana, Habana, police arrested several prominent members of the San Isidro Movement after they visited a companion of theirs. Police say the people were arrested for violating coronavirus measures, but the spokesperson of the group says it was a case of repression of mobility. The people were released after an hour again.
On 1 December 2020, in Santa Clara, Villa Clara, state security forces arrested a rapper who supports the San Isidro Movement. After a few hours he was released again.

On 2 December 2020, in Habana, Habana, police officers arrested several leading figure of the San Isidro Movement. Another journalist member of the group was also arrested. Some of them have been arrested days before and while other were arrested again later that week.

On 9 December 2020, in Habana, Habana, pro-government people - including the cousin of the President of the Committees for the Defense of het Revolution (CDR) - threw stones at the house of an activist of the San Isidro Movement who participated in a hunger strike. The hunger striker was organized to demand the release of a San Isidro artist who was arrested for his activities. No fatalities.

Around 15 December 2020 (as reported), in Habana, Habana, a number of opposition activists of the San Isidro movemen and journalists decided to leave their houses after having been forcibly kept in there by security forces. They were promptly arrested.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: UNPACU: Patriotic Union of Cuba; Labour Group (Cuba)
NOTES: On 13 January 2021, in Santiago de Cuba, Santiago de Cuba, state security forces forcibly arrested the leader of the UNPACU opposition group and took him to an undisclosed location.
On 21 January 2021, in Habana, Habana, a rapper and prominent member of the San Isidro Movement was arrested by police for unknown reasons. He was released again hours later.

On 29 January 2021, in Habana, Habana, the leader of the San Isidro Movement was arrested by state security forces when he was on his way to the capitol to protest. Numerous other prominent activists who wanted to attend this protest were also prevented from doing so or arrested.
On 9 February 2021, in Holguin, Holguin, a curfew was imposed by the government in the city between 17:00 and 5:00 to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

On 22 February 2021, in Habana, Habana, pro-government supporters gathered in front of the house of an activist of the San Isidro Movement who had put a sign with the phrase 'Patria y Vida' (alluding to a popular anti-government song) outside her home. The supporters threw petroleum and paint outside the house and on the facade as part of an act of repudiation. The family dog was also attacked by demonstrators.
On 26 February 2021, in Santiago de Cuba, Santiago de Cuba, the leader of the UNPACU opposition group was arrested by state security forces.

On 26 February 2021, in Santiago de Cuba, Santiago de Cuba, about 20 supporters of the government carried out an act of repudiation outside the UNPACU headquarters. The group threw manure mixed with cement at the building.

On 1 March 2021, in Habana, Habana, supporters of the government held an act of repudiation outside the home of an activist and member of the UNPACU after she painted the phrase 'Patria y Vida' on her house, referring to a popular anti-government song. They painted her house.

Property destruction: On 6 March 2021, in Santiago de Cuba, Santiago de Cuba, pro-government supporters held an act of repudiation outside the headquarters of the UNPACU opposition group. Demonstrators threw stones at the building and played loud music over loudspeakers.

Other: On 20 March 2021, in Santiago de Cuba, Santiago de Cuba, some 45 members of UNPACU started a hunger strike in protest against the Cuban regime. The hunger strikers demanded that they would be allowed to help needy families in the city by providing them with food and other products, something that police has prevented them from doing. In Habana, Holguin, Guantanamo, and other places people have also joined the hunger strike in solidarity.

Property destruction: On 3 April 2021, in Santiago de Cuba, Santiago de Cuba, in an act of repudiation, a pro-government militia threw rocks at the headquarters of UNPACU, whose members have been in hunger strike for two weeks.
On 17 April 2021, in Habana, La Habana, police officers broke into the house of the founder of the San Isidro Movement and arrested he and his partner.

Property destruction: Around 19 April 2021 (as reported), in Habana, La Habana, a video circulating on the web showed police officers breaking into the headquarters of the San Isigro Movement and destroying art works belonging to the founder of the movement.

Property destruction: On 23 April 2021, in Peralejo, Sancti Spiritus, members of a pro-government militia tried to burn the house of the son of a member of the opposition (Territorial Coordinator for the North East). Perpetrators then they fled shouting various slogans in favor of the neo-raulist military alliance in the government.

Strikes: On 25 April 2021, in Habana, La Habana, an activist and founder of the San Isidro Movement (MSI) began a hunger and thirst strike to protest against police repression and the besieging of his house by law enforcement for the past month. Law enforcement officers were posted in the surroundings of his house preventing other activists and friends from visiting the activist. Other activists started hunger strikes in solidarity.

Around 29 April 2021 (as reported), in Cuba (coded to Habana), at least 25 activists, including members of the San Isidro Movement and of the 27 November Movement, were detained by police forces in the street or kept under house detention. The activists had expressed their support and solidarity to another activist on hunger and thirst strike, either in the social networks or with their physical presence in the streets.

On 14 June 2021, in Habana, La Habana, police officers arrested an independent journalist after filming written messages demanding democratic reforms in Cuba and sharing a related post in social media. The journalist was called the next day to the police station and detained there, supposedly to respond to a contempt case opened in 2020 (unreported). The man went on a hunger strike, which he had to depose due to health problems.

Around 11 July 2021 (week of), in Habana, La Habana, a female journalist was arrested for documenting the anti-government demonstrations that occurred nationwide on the same week. Since then, the journalist has been placed under house arrest.

On 11 July 2021, in Santiago de Cuba, Santiago de Cuba, UNPACU leader and his son were arrested by police officers. The men were on their way to one of the demonstrations taking place at the moment, part of a nation-wide protest that occurred on the same day. Also, in Santiago de Cuba, police forces arrested another member of the UNPACU. Officers arrived to the activist's house and seized his identification document. According to witnesses, he was violently taken by the officers.

On 11 July 2021, in Camaguey, Camaguey, police forces arrested two journalists who were at their houses. Allegedly, the journalists were arrested after police received anonymous reports against them. These arrests are part of a wave of arrests of journalists that the police carried out amid anti-government demonstrations.

Other: On 11 July 2021, in Habana, La Habana, President Diaz-Canel called the people supporting the government to go out to the streets to face the protests taking place in multiple provinces of Cuba, qualifying them as 'systematic provocations'. This was a reaction to the nation-wide protest that occurred on the same day.

On 12 July 2021, in Colon, Matanzas, police officers arrested an artist, human rights defender and member of the Citizens Committee for Racial Integration due to his participation in the protests of 11 July 2021 in the same town. This arrest is part of a wave of arrests of activists that the police carried out amid anti-government demonstrations.

On 15 July 2021, in Colon, Matanzas, police and military officers arrested the executive director of the Cuban Institute for Freedom of Expression and Press (ICLEP), Alberto Corzo, at his home. According to his wife, he did not participate in the anti-government demonstrations, since they were at home under siege by the police. The arrest occurred after the ICLEP reported that at least 47 journalists suffered repression during the anti-government demonstrations that started on 11 July 2021.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: UNPACU: Patriotic Union of Cuba; Women (Cuba)
NOTES: On 21 July 2021, in Santiago de Cuba, Santiago de Cuba, police officers arrested an UNPACU activist, the wife of an UNPACU leader. The woman was trying to file a writ of habeas corpus in favor of her husband, who was arrested on 11 July on his way to one of the nationwide demonstrations taking place that day.

On 21 July 2021, in Santiago de Cuba, Santiago de Cuba, police forces arrested an independent journalist who was at his house. This arrest is part of a wave of arrests of journalists that the police carried out amid anti-government demonstrations.

On 23 July 2021, in Marianao, La Habana, police forces arrested an independent journalist who was at his house. This arrest is part of a wave of arrests of journalists that the police carried out amid anti-government demonstrations.

On 24 July 2021, in Habana, La Habana, a State Security agent in civilian clothes arrested an independent journalist who was at his house. This arrest is part of a wave of arrests of journalists that the police carried out amid anti-government demonstrations.

Other: On 17 August 2021, in Habana, La Habana, the Cuban government announced legislation to allegedly restrict freedom of expression on the internet, including the dissemination of fake news, offensive messages, defamation with an 'impact on the country's prestige' and calling for peaceful demonstrations against the government, which is considered a crime of 'cyberterrorism'. This new law was approved amidst the arrest of several demonstrators that participated in the anti-government demonstrations of 11 July. After these demonstrations, the government suspended for several days the internet service and has enlarged the restrictions to access different social media and websites. Several participants of these demonstrations were activists that advocate for freedom of expression.

On 8 September 2021, in Habana, La Habana, police officers arrested an independent journalist and activist in Parque de la Fraternidad, when he was on his way to cover a national religious celebration. The journalist was released the same day and reported having been threatened and invited to 'leave the country'.

On 2 November 2021, in Santa Clara, Villa Clara, the police arrested the general coordinator of the United Anti-Totalitarian Front (FANTU) in front of his house. The reasons for his arrest are unknown. This arrest occurred amidst detentions and acts of repudiation against activists who support the anti-government demonstration scheduled for 25 November.

On 12 November 2021, in Habana, La Habana, security officers wearing plainclothes took a female activist from the Archipelago Group to a house and kept her there during 5 days to prevent her to participate in the anti-government demonstrations 'Civic March for Change' scheduled for 15 November. The woman did not have communication with her family.

On 13 November 2021, in Artemisa, Artemisa, police officers placed a female journalist and director of an independent media outlet under house arrest from 13 to 16 November, to prevent her participation in a demonstration. This act occurred amidst detentions and acts of repudiation against activists and civilians who support the anti-government demonstration 'Civic March for Change' scheduled for 15 November.

On 13 November 2021, in Las Tunas, Las Tunas, a promoter of the anti-government demonstration scheduled for 15 November and coordinator of the organizing collective in Las Tunas was arrested in unreported circumstances. This arrest occurred amidst detentions and acts of repudiation against activists who support the anti-government demonstration 'Civic March for Change' scheduled for 15 November.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: MONR: Opposition Movement for a New Republic; Ladies in White; Women (Cuba)
NOTES: On 14 November 2021, in Habana, La Habana, police officers arrested the leader of the Opposition Movement for a New Republic (MONR) and his wife, a member of the Ladies in White. Circumstances of the arrest are unknown. This arrest occurred amidst detentions and acts of repudiation against activists and civilians who support the anti-government demonstration 'Civic March for Change' scheduled for 15 November

On 14 November 2021, in Santa Clara, Villa Clara, the general coordinator of the United Anti-Totalitarian Front (FANTU) was detained at his house in unknown circumstances. The activist was admitted to the transplant room of the New Hospital of the Santa Clara municipality. This arrest occurred amidst detentions and acts of repudiation against activists who support the anti-government demonstration scheduled for 15 November. The activist was released three days after the confinement against his will.

On 15 November 2021, in Guantanamo, Guantanamo, police officers arrested an activist and coordinator of the Eastern Democratic Alliance (ADO). This act occurred amidst detentions and acts of repudiation against activists and civilians who support the anti-government demonstration 'Civic March for Change' scheduled for 15 November. The man was released the next day, with a warning that he could not leave his home nor travel outside the province.

On 15 November 2021, in Habana, La Habana, police officers arrested the leader of the Ladies in White and her husband, an activist, on their way to participate in the anti-government demonstration scheduled for the day. Circumstances of the arrest are unknown. This arrest occurred amidst detentions and acts of repudiation against activists and civilians who support the anti-government demonstration 'Civic March for Change' scheduled for 15 November.

On 15 November 2021, in Habana, La Habana, police officers arrested an activist and leader of the Council for Democratic Transition in Cuba (CTDC) on his way to participate in the anti-government demonstration scheduled for the day. Circumstances of the arrest are unknown. This arrest occurred amidst detentions and acts of repudiation against activists and civilians who support the anti-government demonstration 'Civic March for Change' scheduled for 15 November.

On 15 November 2021, in Santiago de Cuba, Santiago de Cuba, police officers arrested an activist from UNPACU in unknown circumstances. This arrest occurred amidst detentions and acts of repudiation against activists and civilians who support the anti-government demonstration 'Civic March for Change' scheduled for 15 November.

On 19 November 2021, in Pinar del Rio, Pinar del Rio, three plainclothes security officers arrested a journalist in a vehicle, after he interviewed an activist. According to the activist, he later went to a police station to ask about the journalist, they told him that the journalist was not there. The journalist's whereabouts are unknown.

On 9 December 2021, in Santa Clara, Villa Clara, agents of the State Security arrested the general coordinator of the United Anti-Totalitarian Front (FANTU) in front of his house. The activist was taken by nurses in an ambulance, despite not being ill or having requested any medical appointment or care. The reasons for his arrest are unknown.

On 10 December 2021, in Habana, La Habana, police officers arrested the leader of the Ladies in White and her husband, an activist, after going out on Human Rights Day. Circumstances of the arrest are unknown. This act took place in the midst of a siege against activists and journalists to prevent any demonstration in favour of human rights on their day.
On 28 March 2020, throughout Dominica a curfew was imposed to prevent the spread of coronavirus.
On April 11, 2019, the Dominican government confirmed that over the last 48 hours over 1000 Haitian citizens were arrested due to their undocumented status.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Dominican Republic (2004-2020)
NOTES: On September 17, 2019, in Santo Domingo, the commander in chief of the Dominican Republic_ army said the border with Haiti is now completely sealed shut and no one can pass, due to the unrest in Haiti over fuel shortage.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of the Dominican Republic (2004-2020)
NOTES: Between 02 and 06 January 2020 in Santo Domingo and seven other provinces, 1012 Haitian immigrants were arrested and 939 of them were deported.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Dominican Republic (2004-2020)
NOTES: On 07 January 2020 in the area of Saona island, south of Punta Cana, 35 people were detained by naval officers, arrested and charged with attempting illegal migration to Puerto Rico.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Dominican Republic (2004-2020)
NOTES: On 07 January 2020 in the area of San Pedro de Macoris, 28 people were detained by naval officers, arrested and charged with attempting illegal migration to Puerto Rico.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of the Dominican Republic (2004-2020)
NOTES: On 21 January 2020 in Santo Domingo, 806 haitian immigrants were arrested and handed over to migration authorities. The border police also confiscated several vehicles, tobacco, marihuana, and food that was being transported.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of the Dominican Republic (2004-2020)
NOTES: On 09 February 2020, in La Penita by Boca Chica, 80 Haitian immigrants without documentation were detained and expelled to Haiti.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of the Dominican Republic (2004-2020)
NOTES: Around 12 February 2020 (between 10 February - 13 February), in Santo Domingo, 866 Haitian immigrants were detained and deported from several towns across the Dominican Republic.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of the Dominican Republic (2004-2020)
NOTES: On 15 February 2020 in Santo Domingo and 12 other provinces, at least two thousand immigrants without documents were arrested. Among them were 1500 Haitians who were sent back to Haiti, while the remaining 500, with various nationalities, were detained by immigration authorities.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of the Dominican Republic (2004-2020)
NOTES: Around 10 March 2020 (between 9 - 12 March), in the provinces Azua, Barahona, Santiago, Santiago Rodriguez, Valverde, Duarte, Sanchez Ramirez, Espaillat, Hermanas Mirabal, La Vega and Santo Domingo (coded to Santo Domingo Este), migration officers conducted a mass arrest of 2100 undocumented Haitians in a variety of locations throughout the country which were then deported from the country. Human trafficking of undocumented Haitians is a large criminal enterprise in the Dominican Republic.

Human trafficking of undocumented Haitians is a large criminal enterprise in the Dominican Republic.

On 19 March 2020 the border between Haiti and the Dominican Republic was closed to prevent the spread of coronavirus. On 20 March 2020 throughout the Dominican Republic a curfew was imposed. On 27 March 2020 the curfew was extended.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Dominican Republic (2004-2020)
NOTES: Around 29 May 2020, in San Pedro de Macoris, the navy arrested 34 people who were attempting to make an illegal journey to Puerto Rico. [size=no report]

ACTOR1: Police Forces of the Dominican Republic (2004-2020)
NOTES: Around 11 July 2020 (as reported), near Sabana de la Mar, Hato Mayor, police arrested 27 people attempting to illegally cross out of Puerto Rico in two dinghies.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Dominican Republic (2020-)
NOTES: Around 15 October 2020 (as reported), at the Dominican-Haitian border, nearly 10.000 Dominican troops were mobilized in order to combat human trafficking, following an increase in unrest and gang violence in the north-east of Haiti.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of the Dominican Republic (2020-)
NOTES: On 28 November 2020, in Santo Domingo, Distrito Nacional, the second-in-command of the Village de Dieu Gang, a gang active in Haiti, was arrested by police. He will be handed over to Haitian authorities.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of the Dominican Republic (2020-)
NOTES: On 16 December 2020, in Dajabon, Dajabon, 162 undocumented Haitians were detained and repatriated.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of the Dominican Republic (2020-)
NOTES: On 14 February 2021, in Dajabon, Dajabon, the former mayor of Port-au-Prince was arrested and extradited to Haiti. He allegedly played a part in the alleged planned coup attempt for which 23 people were arrested earlier in February. In his car, weapons were allegedly found. During marches against the government, his image was used by protesters.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Dominican Republic (2020-)
NOTES: Movement of forces: On 22 February 2021, in Jimani, Independencia, six teams of the counter terrorism unit of the Dominican Armed Forces were dispatched to cross the border for a rescue mission to free the Dominican citizens who were abducted days before by extortionists in Haiti.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of the Dominican Republic (2020-)
NOTES: On 24 April 2021, in Dajabon, Dajabon, 234 Haitian immigrants were arrested and handed over to migration authorities during an operation carried out on the Haitian-Dominican border. At least 300,000 cigarettes were seized during the operation.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of the Dominican Republic (2020-)
NOTES: On 7 June 2021, in Santiago province [coded to Santiago de los Santiago de los Caballeros], 80 Haitian migrants were arrested between the municipalities of San Jose de las Matas, Villa Gonzalez, Navarrete, Salcedo and others. The migrants were sent back to their country through the border area of Dajabon.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of the Dominican Republic (2020-)
NOTES: On 9 August 2021, in Santiago de los Caballeros, Santiago, police officers arrested twenty-eight people in a party for breaching the curfew restrictions imposed as a measure to prevent the spread of coronavirus in Padre las Casas sector. A firearm was seized during the arrest.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of the Dominican Republic (2020-)
NOTES: On 17 August 2021, in San Jose de Las Matas, Santiago, the police arrested 45 Haitian migrants in irregular situation, including 15 minors, while traveling in a vehicle through the El Rubio neighbourhood.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of the Dominican Republic (2020-)
NOTES: On 26 August 2021, in Miches, El Seibo, the police arrested 97 people, including 95 Haitian migrants and 2 Dominicans, who planned to migrate irregularly to Puerto Rico in a boat departing from the Boca de Laguna sector.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Dominican Republic (2020-)
NOTES: Security measures: On 1 November 2021, in Dajabon, Dajabon, the Armed Forces deployed troops and staged a military exhibition over the border zone between the Dominican Republic and Haiti. The government deployed 12,000 soldiers to guard the border and control the sale of fuel, to prevent the illegal trafficking of fuel to Haiti amid the crisis in the neighbouring country.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of the Dominican Republic (2020-)
NOTES: On 16 November 2021, near Valverde (coded to Santa Cruz de Mao), the police arrested 44 Haitian migrants in irregular situation and a Dominican man who transported them in a truck.

On 18 February 2018, in San Lorenzo area (Esmeraldas), one day after the event where Ecuadorian Military forces faced an armed unidentified armed group in San Lorenzo, more military forces were mobilized on the border between Ecuador and Colombia. The border is known for the presence of several armed groups, including the FARC, the ELN and the Gulf Clan.
On March 2 2019, after unidentified armed groups clashed in San Lorenzo, in Esmeraldas, around 150 civilians from Colombia moved their homes towards Palma Real, in San Lorenzo, Esmeraldas.
On October 3 2019, in Quito, Pichincha, the Ecuadorean president Lenin Moreno decreed a state of emergency to protect citizens due to the transport demonstrations in the country that were violent.

On 08 October 2019, in Guayaquil, Guayas, President Lenin Moreno established the change of the government headquarters to Guayaquil and announced a curfew because of the increasing violent acts in the country, formalized in Decree 888. The curfew was active from 8pm until 5am from Monday to Sunday in the specific strategic zones, including nearby areas were the government operates and other zones that the military forces establish. This act was implemented to maintain public order in the country.

On 12 October 2019, in Quito, Pichincha, President Lenin Moreno announced a curfew because of the increasing violent acts in the city, that included a militarization of the city. The curfew was active from 3pm in the Distrito Metropolitano de Quito and the surrounding areas.

On 8 February 2020, in Naranjal, Guayas, unidentified men threw a home-made bomb to a journalist's house. The artifact exploded in his garage, but there are no reports of injured. The event happened on the same district where there were reports of similar attacks against a Congresswoman from the PAIS alliance, and a lawyer.

On 13 February 2020, in Naranjal, Guayas, unidentified men threw a home-made bomb and gasoline into the garage of a lawyer. The artifact exploded, but did not ignite the gasoline. The event happened on the same district where there were reports of similar attacks against a Congresswoman from the PAIS alliance, and a journalist.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Government of Ecuador (2007-2021); Women (Ecuador); PAIS Alliance: Proud and Sovereign Fatherland
NOTES: On 13 February 2020, in Naranjal, Guayas, a car and a bike were burned with gasoline by unidentified assailants outside the house of a Congresswoman from PAIS alliance movement. The fire was put out by neighbors. PAIS alliance movement denounced these acts as threats against the Congresswoman. The event happened on the same district where there were reports of similar attacks against a lawyer, and a journalist.

Other: On 24 May 2021, in Quito (Pichincha), Guillermo Alberto Santiago Lasso Mendoza of the Creating Opportunities Party (CREO), was sworn in as the President of Ecuador. The beginning of his term marked the end of 14 years of the PAIS Alliance party in power.

On 10 January 2018, In Lolotique, San Miguel, the police forces of El Salvador found and dismantled a camp belonging to MS-13 gang. An M16 assault rifle was seized, as well as magazines and two backpacks with abundant ammunition for heavy weapons. The camp, according to the Police, was used as a hideout.

On 26 January 2018, the FGR: Republic's General Prosecutor team found three human corpses in an San Luis Talpa, in an area that is being checked by experts. The area has the presence of gangsters. Everyday the authorities of the area receive people with pictures of their disappeared relatives. The FGR team is expecting to find from 15 to 30 corpses in an area of 5 km wide by 7 km long.
On 31 January 2018, in various municipalities of La Union the police forces of El Salvador arrested 52 gang members linked to extortion, homicides and conspiracy.

On 1 February 2018, in different areas of San Sebastian, San Vicente, the police forces of El Salvador arrested 37 members of Downtown Criminales, a faction of M-13 Mara Salvatrucha. The gangsters are accused of conspiracy and illegal limitation of the free movement of people. During the operation the police seized a pickup truck, a motorcycle and several cell phones.

On 19 February 2018, in Santa Ana, Police and military forces of El Salvador arrested 57 gang members accused of forcibly displaced families that refused to pay extortions. Two vehicles and five motorcycles were seizured. The suspects are also accused of attacking two police patrols in recent armed clashes. More than 400 men participated in the operation to capture the gangsters in the areas of Primavera and Santa Leonor in Santa Ana.

On 28 February 2018, in Teotepeque municipality, La Libertad, the National Police dismantled a group of the Mara Salvatrucha that operated in the municipality, 38 gang members were arrested. No fatalities reported.

On 16 March 2018, in Santa Tecla, La Libertad, the police forces conducted an opertion to dismantle a financial structure of the Mara Salvatrucha. 29 people were arrested, among them were 7 members of the gang Mara Salvatrucha. No fatalities reported.

On 17 March 2018, In La Union, the police forces of El Salvador deployed an operation and arrested 40 members of criminal groups. Some of the arrested people are accused of homicide, robbery and extortion. The police said they solved 11 homicides with these arrests. During the operation the police confiscated a pistol, a bulletproof vest, cell phones and tablets. The operation took place in the municipalities of Santa Rosa de Lima, Anamoros, Poloros and Lislique.

Around 30 October 2018 (as reported), in San Vicente department, the police forces arrested 26 people related to organised crime in the municipalities of San Sebastian, Apasteque and San Vicente.

Around 6 November 2018 (as reported), 501 gang members from MS-13 and 18th Street Gang were arrested by the police forces and the Attorney General's Office in La Libertad department. They were arrested under charges such as homicide, femicide and extortion.
