The State of Site was a response to communal violence in a historic territorial dispute between the communities of those localities.

On 1 June 2020, in rural area of Santiago Sacatepequez, police forces found and seized three greenhouses used to produce marijuana. In the operation the police also confiscated chemicals to process cocaine.
On 2 June 2020, in Santa Cruz, rural area of San Luis, Peten, military forces of Belize entered Guatemalan territory without known authorization by the Guatemalan government.

On 3 June 2020, in Santa Catarina Ixtahuacan, Solola, in barrio Paxocal, Police forces found and seized a bunker used to attack rival communal militias. The police confiscated two artisanal bombs and a mortar.
On 19 June 2020, in El Chico village, rural area of Retalhuleu, Retalhuleu, military forces found and seized a burning narco-airplane.
On 2 July 2020, in rural area of Nueva Santa Rosa, Santa Rosa, Police forces found and destroyed a 1,1 hectare coca crop in Jumaytepeque village. A man was arrested.

On 19 July 2020, in El Estor municipality, Izabal, the president of Guatemala declared a state of emergency in the municipalities of El Estor, Livingston and Morales in Izabal, and Santa Catalina La Tinta and Panzos in Alta Verapaz as a response to the increase of gang activities, including attacks against military forces. The State of emergency is bound to last 30 days. On 25 July, congress did not approved the state of emergency, already in place since 19 July. On 16 August, the state of emergency was extended in these municipalities.

On 19 July 2020, in El Estor municipality, Izabal, the president of Guatemala declared a state of emergency in the municipalities of El Estor, Livingston and Morales in Izabal, and Santa Catalina La Tinta and Panzos in Alta Verapaz as a response to the increase of gang activities, including attacks against military forces. The State of emergency is bound to last 30 days. On 25 July, congress did not approved the state of emergency, already in place since 19 July. On 16 August, the state of emergency was extended in these municipalities.
Around 20 July 2020 (from 20 July - 21 July), in rural area of Livingston, Izabal, police and military forces found and destroyed crops with a total of with 36,836 coca plants in Santa Cruz village.
On 21 July 2020, in El Estor municipality, Izabal, police forces found and destroyed crops with 4,060 coca plants, in San Pablo II village.
On 22 July 2020, in Momostenango municipality, Totonicapan, police forces found and destroyed a crop of 4,700 marijuana plants in Xequemeya village.

On 26 July 2020, in Santa Ana municipality, Peten, military and police forces found and confiscated a burning airplane and more than 2,107 kilos of cocaine buried nearby in Los Angeles. Two all-terrain vehicles were also seized.

Security measures: On 27 July 2020, in Guatemala City, Guatemala City, the President declared a State of Emergency for 15 days in Izabal, Santa Catarina Ixtahuacan and Nahuala, in Solola department, Puerto Barrios and Santo Tomas de Castilla. The government argued that the security measure seeks to fight armed groups in the area.
On 6 August 2020, in Ixcan municipality, El Quiche, military forces found and seized a burned airplane used for drug trafficking, in Santa Cruz village.

On 6 August 2020, in San Luis municipality, Peten, military forces found and destroyed 1.2 hectares of coca and a lab to produce cocaine, in Boloczos village. Two fire guns were confiscated and one man was arrested.
On 7 August 2020, in Retalhuleu municipality, Retalhuleu, police and military forces seized and destroyed an illegal airstrip used for drug trafficking, in El Chico village.
On 7 August 2020, in El Manchon Guamuchal, Retalhuleu, police and military forces seized and destroyed an illegal airstrip used for drug trafficking.

On 16 August 2020, in Coban municipality, Alta Verapaz, 40 Maya families were violently displaced from their homes by an armed group in Cubilguitz farm. The perpetrators, presumably linked to a land lord, burned six houses and the belongings of the displaced families.
On 21 August 2020, in El Naranjo, Peten, police and military forces found and seized a crashed airplane containing a cocaine cargo. The drug seized is valued in USD 9 million.

On 14 September 2020, in Rubelsanto, Alta Verapaz, military and police forces found and destroyed a clandestine airstrip used for drug trafficking. Some residents blocked the road to the airstrip with trees, but the police cleared the road.

On 23 September 2020, in Coban municipality, Alta Verapaz, military forces found and seized a crashed airplane with a drug cargo in Santa Marta Salinas village. Three packs of drugs were confiscated. Two corpses were found nearby the airplane.

On 26 September 2020, in Ayutla municipality, San Marcos, police forces found and destroyed a narco lab in Sanjon San Lorenzo. One pistol, a shot gun drugs, communication equipment and cash were also seized.

Security measures: On 2 October 2020, in Guatemala City, Guatemala City, the President declared a State of Prevention for 15 days in Izabal, Jutiapa, Zacapa, Chiquimula, El Progreso, and Peten departments to contain potential migratory flows from Honduras.
On 3 November 2020, in San Andres Municipality, Peten, authorities found three dead bodies and cocaine inside an airplane that had entered Guatemala on 29 October 2020.

On 6 November 2020, in Guatemala City, the President declared a State of Emergency for 30 days in Peten, Izabal, Quiche, Alta Verapaz, Zacapa, El Progreso, Jutiapa and Santa Rosa district, for strong rains. 50 people died as a result of the tropical storm.

On 11 November 2020, in Champerico, Retalhuleu, authorities seized 1028 packs of cocaine - worth 14 million American dollars -, satellite telephones, GPS, cell phones, American dollars, and Colombian pesos that were left inside an airplane.
On 11 November 2020, in San Andres Municipality, Peten, authorities seized 1,539 kilograms of cocaine left inside a destroyed airplane in Laguna del Tigre.

On 19 December 2020, La Libertad Municipality, Peten (coded to La Libertad), police forces in coordination with the Public Ministry and the Ministry of Defense found and seized an airplane used to transport drugs that crashed in National Park Cierra de Lacandon. Authorities found 150 packs of cocaine, two firearms, one radio, one satellite phone and a GPS. According to reports, three men were on the plane. Two of them were arrested and the other one died in the crash.

On 23 December 2020, in El Manchon Guamuchal, Retalhuleu, authorities seized 510 packs of cocaine - worth 7 million American dollars -, 16 cell phones and two travel logs that were left inside an airplane- identified with a Mexican flag that landed in El Chico area. 15 people were arrested.
On 30 December 2020, in San Andres Municipality, Peten, authorities seized 339 packs of cocaine that were left inside an airplane that landed in the Laguna del Tigre National Park.

On 31 December 2020, in Guatemala City, Guatemala, the Police arrested the ''treasurer'' of the Mara 18 gang. According to reports, the arrested suspect is in charge of coordinating armed attacks and establishing the addresses of homes or businesses that should be extorted in areas of zone 6 and zone 18.
On 10 January 2021, in La Libertad municipality, Peten (coded to La Libertad), military forces found and seized an airplane used to transport drugs.

On 12 January 2021, in Chiquimula municipality, Chiquimula, police officers located 48 Honduran immigrants in two buses, at height 177 of the Interamerican Highway. The immigrants were handed over to the immigration authority where they were detained. They are suspected to be part of a significant migrant caravan heading to United States.
On 13 January 2021, in Guatemala City, Guatemala, the government declared the State of Alarm in 7 departments to contain migratory flows.

On 13 January 2021, in Cayuga, Izabal, the National Police found a narco laboratory and 2.150 coca plants, along with two jars of caustic soda, a bag of bicarbonate, a barrel with chopped coca leaves inside, and cement.

On 15 January 2021, in El Florido checkpoint (coded to Caparja), Chiquimula at least 4,500 Honduran migrants traveling on foot to the United States entered Guatemala, after breaking a police siege shouting 'we want to pass.' No major incidents were reported.
On 17 January 2021, in Guatemala City, Guatemala, the government deployed 5,000 members of the Military Forces to support the security plan to prevent the illegal passage of migrants.
On 31 January 2021, in the Peten department (coded to Flores), military forces found and seized an airplane used to transport drugs.

On 18 February 2021, in San Andres municipality, Peten, military forces found a burned airplane used to transport drugs. According to reports, it was set on fire by alleged drug traffickers, who also placed spikes to prevent them from passing. Two abandoned boats and two rifles were located, as well.
On 21 February 2021, Sayaxche, Peten, military forces found and seized an airplane used to transport drugs.
On 21 February 2021, in San Andres municipality, Peten, military forces found and seized an airplane used to transport drugs.

On 4 March 2021, in Malacatan municipality, San Marcos, the government declared a State of Prevention for 15 days due to recent episodes of civil unrest over the discontinuing of electricity services in the area.

Property destruction: On 20 March 2021, in Santa Cruz Barillas municipality, Huehuetenango, police forces found, seized, and destroyed a crop of 4,669 suspected marijuana plants in Puente Alto village.

Security measures: On 29 March 2021, in Guatemala City, Guatemala, the government declared the State of Prevention for 15 days in Izabal, Zacapa, Chiquimula, El Progreso, and Peten departments to contain potential migratory flows from Honduras.

Security measures: On 16 April 2021, in Guatemala (coded to Guatemala City), the government declared the State of Prevention for fifteen days in the entire country amid an increase of coronavirus pandemic infections.

Property destruction: On 24 April 2021, in La Libertad Municipality, Peten (coded to La Libertad), military forces and members of the Public Ministry found and seized an airplane used to transport drugs that crashed in National Park Sierra de Lacandon. The airplane was burned, and authorities found 230 packets of cocaine 12 KM away from the scene.

On 25 April 2021, at the height of KM 181.5 of the Pacific Route in Retalhuleu municipality, Retalhuleu department, state police officers detained 61 migrants from Chile, Cuba, Haiti, Ecuador, Brazil, French Guyana, and Africa in a bus. The migrants were transferred to the Migration Institute.

Property destruction: On 27 April 2021, in Chiantla municipality, Huehuetenango department, the national police found in Las Tejas canton, Los Regadillos, 21 tons of acetic anhydride, a substance used for the production of synthetic drugs.

Property destruction: On 20 May 2021, in Sayaxche municipality, Peten, military forces found an airplane used to transport drugs. According to reports, when authorities searched the plane, they found 1,056 packs of cocaine.
Property destruction: On 21 May 2021, in San Andres Municipality, Peten, military forces found and seized an airplane used to transport drugs.
On 22 May 2021, in Guatemala City, Guatemala, the police arrested 171 people for not complying with biosecurity measures imposed by the Government amid the coronavirus pandemic.

Property destruction: On 31 May 2021, in Livingston, Izabal, military forces found and seized the burnt parts of an airplane used to transport drugs. In addition, the police found two bodies and 46 packets of cocaine.

Non-violent activity: On 12 June 2021, in Nenton municipality, Huehuetenango, an unidentified armed group established an illegal checkpoint on the road that connects Comitan with Chiapas, Mexico. According to the reports, hooded armed men in bulletproof cars make people stop and get out of their cars and check their vehicles.

On 11 July 2021, in Villa Nueva, Guatemala, 96 people were arrested in a nightclub in 2 Zone for not complying with the biosecurity measures adopted by the National Government amid the coronavirus pandemic.

Security measures: On 13 July 2021, in Guatemala (coded to Guatemala City), the government declared the State of Prevention for fifteen days in the entire country amid an increase in the rate of patients infected with coronavirus. It is the second state of prevention declared in the country in 2021 amid the coronavirus pandemic.
On 16 July 2021, in Guatemala City, Guatemala, 25 people were arrested at a party in 10 Zone for not complying with the curfew and the coronavirus pandemic measures adopted by the government.

On 17 July 2021, in Escuintla department, Escuintla, members of the police forces rescued 145 migrants. According to the report, 117 Haitians, 13 Cubans, six Venezuelan, four Brazilian, three Chilean, one Nicaraguan and one Pilipino were hidden inside the container of a vehicle. One person was arrested.
On 1 August 2021, in Villa Canales, Guatemala, police forces rescued 101 Haitian migrants that were hidden in a warehouse located in colonia Brisas del Valle.
On 1 August 2021, in Coatepeque, Quetzaltenango, police forces arrested 65 migrants from Haiti, Chile, Camerum, Angola, and Brazil. No more details are provided by the report.

Security measures: On 13 August 2021, in Guatemala department (coded to Guatemala City), the government declared the State of Calamity for thirty days in the entire country amid an increase in the rate of patients infected with the coronavirus. Measures include a curfew from 10 PM to 4 AM. On 3 September 2021, the Executive branch mandated mobility restrictions for all citizens and vehicles from 8 PM to 4 AM.

On 29 August 2021, in Escuintla municipality, Escuintla, members of the police forces rescued migrants who made an irregular entry to the country at height KM 61, 33. According to the report, 22 Haitians, 4 Hondurans, three Venezuelan, two Uzbeks and one Nicaraguan were circulating in two cars. Two men were arrested.

Looting: On 5 September 2021, in Livingston, Izabal, military forces and police forces found and seized 1,000 kilos of cocaine, five firearms, and ammunition near the Sarstun river, in the Toquela caserio.

On 10 September 2021, in Guatemala City, Guatemala City, police forces arrested 50 people in the Cardales de Cayala neighborhood in Zone 16 for violating the Dry Law. The arrest was carried out in an operation to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

On 18 September 2021, in Guatemala City, Guatemala City, police forces arrested 107 people in a club in Zone 10 for violating the Dry Law and for not complying with the social distance, the use of masks, and hand sanitizer. The massive arrest was carried out in operation to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.
Looting: On 24 September 2021, in San Luis, Peten, military forces found and seized a burned airplane used to transport drugs. The plane made an illegal landing in the El Rosal village.
On 26 September 2021, in the outskirts of Huite, Zacapa, police forces arrested 75 Haitian and Cuban migrants that were in a bus, at height KM 139 near La Reforma village.

On 9 October 2021, in the outskirts of Nueva Concepcion, Escuintla, the police detained 126 migrants who were hidden inside a container at height KM 14 of the road from Cocales to Nueva Concepcion. According to the report, the majority were Haitian and some others from Nepal and Ghana. Migrants were taken to the Guatemalan Institute for Migrations.
Looting: On 10 October 2021, in Puerto San Jose, Escuintla, military forces found and seized a ship used to transport drugs.

On 19 October 2021, in the outskirts of San Andres Villa Seca, Retalhuleu, the police detained 41 Haitian migrants who were left and abandoned between reed beds. Migrants were taken to the Guatemalan Institute for Migrations.

Security measures: On 24 October 2021, in Guatemala City, Guatemala City, the President declared the State of Emergency for El Estor, Izabal Department for 30 days after clashes between the police and protesters, primarily members of the Mayan Q'eqchi' community. The state of siege restricts the right of assembly and demonstration, possession, and bearing of arms, among other rights.

Movement of forces: On 25 October 2021, in the outskirts of El Estor, Izabal, the government deployed 500 military officers and 350 police officers in the area where members of the Mayan Q'eqchi' community were on a sit-in demonstration since 4 October 2021 against the preparatory process of pre-consultation for a mining project of the Guatemalan Nickel Company CGN and a Russian company Solway, promoted by the government. This measure follows a state of siege declared by the government to restore public order after clashes between demonstrators and police officers recorded between 22 and 23 October.

On 31 October 2021, in in Guatemala City, Guatemala City, police officers arrested 129 people who were a night club in zone 9 for the violation of the Dry Law and the biosecurity measures taken to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.
On 31 October 2021, in San Marcos, San Marcos, police officers arrested 163 people who were at different night clubs in zone 2 for the violation of the Dry Law.

Property destruction: On 2 November 2021, in Livingston, Izabal, more than 1,000 police officers evicted a group of Mayan indigenous families and set their houses on fire. A recent ordinance issued that settlers were illegally occupying private lands.

On 2 November 2021, in the outskirts of Guatemala City, Guatemala, police officers arrested 54 Haitian migrants that were left in a wagon at height KM 34 of the route to the Pacific. The migrants were taken to the El Florido, in the border between Guatemala and Honduras. Two drivers were arrested.
Looting: On 5 November 2021, in Champerico, Retalhuleu, police forces found, seized and incinerated an airplane ship used to transport drugs.

Property destruction: On 7 November 2021, in Sayaxche municipality, Peten, the Guatemalan military forces seized an airplane that landed illegally near the Sepensen community. Two vehicles, two bags and six packs with 35 kg of cocaine were also seized. Six people were arrested. The airplane was incinerated by authorities on that day.

Property destruction: On 10 November 2021, in Purulha, Baja Verapaz, police officers evicted a group of Mayan indigenous families from the San Rafael Farm and set their houses on fire. A recent ordinance issued that settlers were illegally occupying private lands.

Property destruction: On 17 November 2021, in Chinebal, El Estor, Izabal, police officers evicted a group of 96 Mayan indigenous families and set their houses on fire. A recent ordinance issued that settlers were illegally occupying private lands.

On 18 November 2021, in Retalhuleu municipality, Retalhuleu, the police detained 59 migrants at height KM 205 of the road to Coatepeque, Quetzaltenango. According to the report, the majority were Haitian and Brazilian. Migrants were taken to the Guatemalan Institute for Migrations.

Security measures: On 22 November 2021, in Guatemala City, Guatemala City, the President declared the State of Prevention for El Estor, Izabal Department, for 15 days. This measure comes after a 30-day State of Emergency due to the clashes between the police and protesters, primarily members of the Mayan Q'eqchi' community.
Defusal: On 28 November 2021, in Guatemala City, Guatemala, police officers defused a grenade that did not exploit after it was thrown at them by suspected criminals in zone 2.
Property destruction: On 3 December 2021, near San Luis, Peten, authorities destroyed 18,000 coca leaf bushes planted in 10 thousand square meters in the community of El Pilar.

Around 2 April 2018 (as reported), in the Barima-Waini region, a number of additional troops were sent to the border region between Venezuela and Guyana to help protect gold miners that are active in this region, after reports of attacks and extortion by members of the Venezuelan Sindicato gang. In January a video was posted to social media of Sindicato members beheading a young Guyanese miner in Venezuela for not paying them.
On 27 March 2020, New Amsterdam and Linden, the second and third largest towns in Guyana imposed curfews to prevent the spread of coronavirus.
On 3 April 2020, througout Guyana, a curfew was imposed to prevent the spread of coronavirus.

On 30 June 2020, in Georgetown, the car belonging to an investigative journalist was set on fire by unknown perpetrators. The car was parked at the guarded parking lot of the Ministry of Public Service. The fire department confirmed that this was a deliberate arson.
On 8 July 2020, in Suddie, Pomeroon-Supernaam, unknown individuals attempted to set fire to the magistrates court using kerosene. [size=no report]

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Police Forces of Guyana (2015-2020); Military Forces of Guyana (2015-2020)
NOTES: On 14 July 2020, in Anna Regina, Pomeroon-Supenaam, a man set fire to two government buildings: an office of the Criminal Investigations Department and another building belonging to the armed forces. [size=1]
On 22 July 2020, in Georgetown, Demerara-Mahaica, a molotov cocktail was thrown at the embassy of Suriname to Guyana. [size=no report]

On 26 July 2020, in Georgetown, Demerara-Mahaica, unknown individuals smashed the windows of the office of the Guyana's Human Rights Association and then ignited a tire, throwing it inside. The neighbours managed to raise the alarm and the fire was extinguished soon after.

On 2 August 2020, in Guyana, the President Irfaan Ali (PPP/C: People's Progressive Party/Civic) and Prime Minister Philips were sworn into office, five months after the election was held. During these five months a long and contested recount was held after the initial results were found to be fraudulent. Originally, the victory was attributed to the APNU-AFC party alliance but eventually given to the PP/C after vote recount.

Arrests: On 25 August 2020, in Abary, Mahaica-Berbice, the Returning Officer for Region 4 of Guyana and his assistant were arrested on election forgery charges. After the March 2020 elections, inconsistencies in vote counts were found in Region 4 which led to a recount being held and a months-long delay occurring between the vote and the announcement of results.

On 21 January 2021, off the coast of Barima-Waini, the Venezuelan navy detained two fishing boats with 12 fishermen on board and instructed them to go to Venezuelan territory where they were arrested. This arrest comes closely after Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro vowed to 'reconquer' the disputed Essequibo territory. Days later, a third fishing vessel with 7 people on board was intercepted in similar circumstances but in Venezuelan territorial waters.

Displacement: On 13 March 2018, in Anse-a-Pitre, Sud-Est, up to 700 Haitians arrived to seek refuge after having fled from the Dominican Republic following an outburst of violence against Haitians there. According to the mayor of Anse-a-Pitre, several Haitians had been killed in the Dominican Republic.

SOURCE: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
NOTES: On 9 April 2018, in Port-au-Prince (Ouest), overnight, unidentified armed men attacked the outside of the headquarters of the RNDDH, the National Human Rights Defense Network, shooting at it. An envelope with a threatening message and bullets were left at the scene.

Around 17 April 2018 (as reported), in Leogane (Ouest), unidentified armed gang members attacked the court house, spreading faecal matter on it and forcing it to close down. Motive unknown and no deaths nor injuries reported.
On 14 July 2018, Haiti Prime Minister Jack Guy Lafontant resigned following deadly violence and looting sparked by a now-abandoned plan to raise fuel prices.

On 27 August 2018, in Miragoane, Nippes, an unidentified group of people vandalized the city hall of Miragoane, destroying windows by throwing rocks and bottles, after the mayor had arrested a man who had threatened him earlier that day.
On 3 November 2018, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, police forces arrested 80 gang members of the Village de Dieu gang in Village de Dieu neighborhood. The officers were unable to catch the gang leader.

On 19 November 2018, the residence of a politician associated with the Fusion of Haitian Social Democrats party located in Chalon, was burned. According to an MP of social-democratic party in Haiti, the attack was by gang members of a gang led by Loulou, who are close to the Haitian Party Tet Kale.

On 2 December 2018, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, police arrested over 60 people during a security operation in the La Saline neighbourhood, among which wanted gang members. They also seized a number of firearms.
On 3 December 2018, the Haitian police arrested 88 gang members in a large operation aiming to reduce gang violence in the capital city, Port-au-Prince.
On February 27 2019, the second leader of the Ti Je Gang was arrested by the police forces of the city of Carrefour, Petit-Goave, Leogane, Ouest, Haiti.

SOURCE: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
NOTES: On 8 March 2019, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gang members operating under the command of Jimmy Cherizier (Delmas 6) set fire to a dozen houses in the Nan Tokyo neighbourhood.

Property destruction: On 16 April 2019, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, armed men invaded and set fire to the Croix de Bossales market. Armed suspects also prevented firefighters from extinguishing the fire, ordering them to turn around. According to traders, the arson could be related to a rivalry between criminal groups that fight for the control of the market. No fatalities or injuries reported.

On 28 May 2019, the Ti Hougan Gang gave up eight firearms in a symbolic ceremony with the National Commission for Disarmament in Cite Soleil, Haiti, attended by authorities and police. A written statement of the gang declared that 'We decided to enter the disarmament program step by step. This shows our willingness to contribute to peace like all citizens.'

On June 18, 2019, in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, gunmen fired at the building of the TV Zenith Radio station. No injuries were reported. Several media outlets and journalists have been targeted in the weeks before.

On June 19, 2019, in Turgeau, Port-au-Prince, Haiti, several people on motorcycles threw stones at a car belonging to the Radio Tele Metropole media station, whom they accused of supporting the president. Several media and journalists have been targeted in the weeks before.
On June 22, 2019, in Les Cayes, Haiti, an unidentified group set fire to the entrance of the VPS Radio station. Several other media organisations were targeted in the preceding weeks.
Around 27 June 2019, in Grand-Goave, Haiti, an unidentified group set fire to four government buildings. Reportedly this was related to the movement demanding the resignation of the president.
On July 22, 2019, the prime minister of Haiti resigned after less than six months in office, after days of violent protests against fuel price rises.

On July 22, 2019, at Cayes City, one of the country_ most wanted gang leaders was arrested at a hospital. He had been hiding out in the Artibonite area since November 2018, robbing cars and merchandise and kidnapping people.
On 5 August 2019, in Port-au-Prince, a head of the gang Bwadom was arrested in Martissant.

Property destruction: On 18 August 2019, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, a group of several armed men invaded and set fire to the Croix de Bossales market during the night. Armed suspects also fired shots. According to merchants, fire is used as a weapon by members of criminal groups who fight over the control of the market. No fatalities or injuries reported.

On September 03, 2019, the deputy of the OPL and a party member of Fanmi Lavalas, both members of the opposition, ransacked the sitting room of the Lower House in order to block the ratification of the general policy of the the newly appointed Prime Minister, Fritz William Michel, which was due to take place in the Lower House several hour later.

Property destruction: On 25 October 2019, in Mirebalais, Centre, a police car was burned. The vehicle was parked and no one was inside. Recently in this area, armed men have perpetrated attacks against residents.
On October 27, 2019, in Port-au-Prince, the judiciary is closing down, postponing all cases, due to attacks, looting and fires on the courthouse and insecurity for the workers there.

SOURCE: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
NOTES: On November 1, 2019, in Bel-Air, Port-au-Prince, after government officials had requested and offered money to local militants to remove all barricades in the area and they refused; gang members, mainly from the Base Krache Dife were given the task.

SOURCE: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
NOTES: On November 7, 2019, in Bel-Air, Port-au-Prince, armed individuals from the Base Krache Dife, dressed in red and black, took over control of the area, several inhabitants left their homes in the area.

On 29 November 2019 in Jacmel, a former MP was arrested, together with 7 others, with firearms, grenades, ammunition, a gas mask and communication equipment. He is charged with threats to state security and to the American embassy and other buildings.

ACTOR1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
NOTES: Property destruction: On 18 December 2019, in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Artibonite, nearly a dozen houses were looted and set on fire by alleged members of Baz Gran Grif gang in the area called Moge. No injuries or fatalities occurred.

Non-violent activity: On 19 December 2019, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, armed men broke into a building belonging to Salesians catholic community in La Saline neighborhood. No damages caused to the building or direct violent actions against civilians were reported by the source during the assault. The area is known for constant clashes between rival gangs that seek to control the neighborhood. No fatalities occurred.
On 26 January 2020, in the district of Saint-Marc, Artibonite (coded to Saint-Marc), police arrested two alleged leaders of the 7 Secondes Gang.

SOURCE: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Le Nouvelliste
NOTES: On 19 February 2020, in Port-au-Prince, the office of the president of the human rights organization Fondation Je Klere: FJKL was vandalized, burning tires left by the entrance, six vehicles and a generator were set on fire, there were bullet holes, rocks, and glass around the building. The FJKL president had been vocal against the creation of the union for police officers.

Property destruction: On 20 February 2020, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, armed men set fire to the stalls that were supposed to accommodate the presidential delegation during the celebration of carnival on the same day. The celebration has been called out as unethical by locals as a considerable part of the population live in poverty.
On 20 March 2020, a state of emergency was declared in Haiti, closing the country's borders and airports and imposing a curfew on its citizens to prevent the spread of coronavirus.

Property destruction: On 10 April 2020, in Thomazeau, Ouest department, police forces carried out a operation against the 400 Mawozo Gang in which police set fire to motorcycles and several small homes.

Property destruction: On 26 April 2020, overnight, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest department, at least seven houses were set on fire by unidentified armed individuals who were trying to leave the Village de Dieu area after the Justice Minister left people 72-hourto leave the area.

Property destruction: On 3 May 2020, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest department, in the afternoon, armed gang members from the Village de Dieu area of the city set fire to the buildings of the Association of Driver Guides of Haiti.

Property destruction: On 8 May 2020, in Miragoane, Nippes department, police officers set fire to seven motorbikes, as well as shooting teargas and bullets, in order to force people to adhere to the coronavirus related measures.
On 10 May 2020, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest department, the office of the human rights group RNDDH was shot at multiple times by unknown assailants during the night.
On 17 May 2020, in Jacmel, Sud-Ouest department, unknown individuals destroyed a quarantine center for coronavirus patients, and then set it on fire.

SOURCE: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
NOTES: On 18 May 2020, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, unknown individuals poured sugar into the generator of the Palace of Justice, destroying it. The electrical wiring connecting to the courthouse were cut.

On 20 May 2020, in Arcahaie municipality, Ouest department, in reprisal to the death of a young man a day prior, inhabitants from Carries set several properties on fire. The conflict is an on-going land disputes between inhabitants from Carries and Fonts Baptiste.

On 20 May 2020, in Montrouis, Artibonite department, a group of armed men burned down beach properties and vehicles. The armed men threatened to burn down everything and cut the heads of the residents of the area. No motive was mentioned. 0 fatalities.

Around 8 June 2020, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest department, a medical research and treatment center which had been working on the treatment of coronavirus was destroyed in a fire. The center was located in a part of the city where gang violence has flared in recent weeks, and had been victim to banditry and threats.

Property destruction: On 11 June 2020, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, members of an armed gang from Nan Bannan'n invaded the territory of a gang from Shada 2, and set fire to at least 12 houses. No gunfire was reported.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Delmas 6 Gang; Baz Pilat Gang; Ti Junior Gang; Base Nan Tokyo Gang
SOURCE: Le Nouvelliste; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
NOTES: On 12 June 2020, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest department, the creation of an alliance of 9 armed gangs, including Delmas 6 Gang, Baz Pilat Gang, Ti Junior Gang, Base Nan Tokyo Gang, was announced under the leadership of Jimmy Cherizier alias Barbecue.

On 15 June 2020, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, the municipal government in cooperation with the police started demolishing houses in the Shada 2 neighbhourhood in retaliation against the Ajivit Gang. In clashes between this gang and the Nan Bannann' Gang the week before six people were killed, including a police officer.

On 15 June 2020, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, the police arrested 30 people connected to the Ajivit Gang, who the authorities hold responsible for the death of a police officer the week before in clashes between this gang and the Nan Bannann' Gang.

Arrests: On 25 July 2020, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, the police arrested six gang members including the gang leader of the 17 Euros Gang, a gang active in Nan Remy neighbourhood. According to police the gang was responsible for at least 12 killings in recent years.

Change to armed group: Around 2 August 2020 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, a number of gangs in the Cite Soleil area came together and formed the G-Pep La coalition under the leadership of Ti Gabriel, in response to the formation of the G-9 gang coalition earlier this year.

Around 26 August 2020 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, police arrested the number 2 of the Ti Junior Gang which is active in La Saline and one of the main actors in the ongoing gang war in the Cite Soleil. During the announcement, police also said that since the launch of 'Operation Terminator 1' more than 50 people had been arrested among whom 11 400 Mawozo Gang members.

On 2 September 2020, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, the gang leader of the Simon-Pele Gang, one of the allies of the G-9, was arrested by the police. Following his arrest, heavy gunfire was heard in the Simon-Pele and Bel Air neighbourhoods, and several houses were set on fire.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Labour Group (Haiti); Police Forces of Haiti (2017-)
NOTES: Property destruction: On 16 September 2020, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, unidentified armed individuals on a motorbike and in a pick-up truck arrived at a popular restaurant and set fire to the premise before getting away. The owner of the restaurant is a high ranking police officer, who days earlier allegedly told police officers to stop their violent demonstrations. No fatalities.
On 1 October 2020, in Jacmel, Sud-Est, unknown individuals set fire to the gate of the city hall of Jacmel.

On 5 October 2020, in Leogane, Ouest, unknown individuals attempted to set a bank on fire with motor oil. The attack is allegedly connected to a new legislation which forces banks to run transactions in the national currency at a benchmark rate.

On 7 October 2020, in Leogane, Ouest, unknown individuals shot at a bank office. The attack is allegedly connected to a new legislation which forces banks to run transactions in the national currency at a benchmark rate. No fatalities.

On 8 October 2020, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunfire were heard in the Bel Air neighbourhood throughout the day. Burning barricades were also erected. It is not reported who was shooting or who erected the barricades. No fatalities. [size=no report]
Property destruction: On 9 October 2020, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, unknown individuals wearing balaclavas set fire to the courthouse.

Around 15 October 2020 (month of), outside Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, gang members destroyed several temporary shelters in a camp for people who were displaced following the earthquake of January 2010. The gang members set the shelters on fire following a dispute with another gang. No fatalities.
Around 15 November 2020 (month of), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, a leading member of the Base 5 Secondes Gang was arrested.

Property destruction: On 27 November 2020, in Petit-Goave, Ouest, unknown individuals set fire to the town hall, destroying a number of documents as well as causing significant material damage to the building. Circumstances unknown.

Looting: On 22 December 2020, outside Port-au-Prince, Ouest, members of the 400 Mawozo Gang disguised as police officers of the Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP) disarmed eight officers of the National Palace General Security Unit (USGPN) in the Morne-a-Capri village north of the capital. The gang members took six rifles, eight pistols, two radios as well as a large sum of money.

On 5 January 2021, in Gonaives, Artibonite, police burned down a Voodoo temple and arrested the priest on allegations of having provided help to local gangs. According to police, the temple was used by gangs as a base of operations.

On 9 January 2021, in Lascahobas, Centre, unknown men set fire to the local church. Gunfire was heard throughout the city and barricades of flaming tires were erected. According to reports, a network of armed gangs caused this violence. No fatalities.

On 28 January 2021, in Jacmel, Sud-Est, a restaurant belonging to the general secretary of the South East region was set on fire. The fire spread to five houses. The owner accuses the political opposition of having orchestrated this act.

Property destruction: On 29 January 2021, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, unidentified men set fire to a garage belonging to the National Police of Haiti in an area controlled by the G-9 Gang. The police did not confirm or affirm that a police operation against the G-9 gang was held in the area.

On 2 February 2021, in Gonaives, Artibonite, unknown individuals attempted to set fire to a hotel owned by the Departmental Director of Public Works. Two vehicles belonging to the state were also set on fire.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Judges (Haiti); Lawyers (Haiti); Police Forces of Haiti (2017-); Government of Haiti (2017-)
NOTES: On 7 February 2021, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, 23 individuals including a high ranking judge who was appointed as provisional President by the opposition, and the inspector general of the Police Forces of Haiti were arrested on charges of conspiring to commit a coup d'etat against President Moise. According to the president there was a plot to kill him and take power and reportedly weapons and money were seized. The judge says that the agents who arrested him beat him during the arrest.

Property destruction: Around 14 February 2021 (as reported), near Gonaives, armed men stopped the driver of a Carnival float on the road to Port-de-Paix. The float was then set on fire by the armed men. Sporadic gunfire was also heard throughout the city on this night.
Property destruction: On 18 March 2021, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, hooded and armed men punctured the tires of more than 20 cars, paralyzing traffic.

Around 7 May 2021 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, after negotiation with the National Commission for Disarmament, Dismantling and Reintegration (CNDDR), the armed groups of Grand-Ravine and Village-de-Dieu agreed to take a two-month pause. The gangs committed not to carry out any act of kidnapping during this period.
Security measures:: On 22 May 2021, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, a 8-day state of health emergency took effect in Haiti as a measure against the spread of the coronavirus.

Non-violent activity: On 12 June 2021, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, armed gang members erected barricades and circulated in the area with war weapons in what seems to be a gang road block. Shots were heard all day long. No fatalities or injuries reported.
Non-violent activity: On 14 June 2021, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, armed gangs, among which alleged members of the G-9 gang, paraded on the main road leading to Toussaint Louverture airport.

Property destruction: On 15 June 2021, in Centre department (coded to Hinche), the Peligre power plant was attacked by armed men with the complicity of security agents responsible for protecting personnel and equipment. According to the Minister of Public Works, Transport and Communications, this was an attempt to thwart the 24-hour electricity project of the President Moise.
Displacement: Around 15 June 2021 (month of), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, more than 8,500 residents were displaced by gang violence and clashes between rival gangs in the area during the whole month.

Non-violent activity: On 17 June 2021, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, a group of armed men pointing their firearms at drivers and passengers of public transport, ordering them to put their vehicles across the road. No fatalities nor injuries reported.

Property destruction: On 17 June 2021, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, the Camp Lapiste center for people with disabilities was burnt down by armed gang members. No fatalities or injuries reported.

Property destruction: On 21 June 2021, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, a bank agency in Martissant 15 was attacked during the night by armed gang members. The Gran Ravin, Village de Dieu and Ti Bwa gangs are known to fight for the control of the area. No fatalities or injuries reported.

Property destruction: On 1 July 2021, in Cabaret, Archaie, gang members set fire to a hangar at premises of the Cimenterie Nationale (CINA), in Fonds-Mombin area. This action is part of a wave of attacks against the private sector which the gangs accused of being responsible for the country's poverty. No fatalities or injuries occurred.

Property destruction: On 2 July 2021, in Cabaret, Archaie, gang members attacked the premises of the Cimenterie Nationale (CINA), in Fonds-Mombin area. One of them was arrested by police officers who were securing the area. This event was part of a wave of attacks against CINA and other private sector businesses in Haiti, which the gangs have accused of being responsible for the country's poverty. No fatalities or injuries occurred.

Security measures: On 7 July 2021, in Port-au-Prince, Port-au-Prince, Ouest, the Council of Ministers, chaired by Prime Minister Claude Joseph, declared a 'state of siege' throughout Haiti for a period of 15 days. This measure allows to deploy the military and police forces to secure the public order also, the country's borders were closed. The measure was taken hours after the killing of President Jovenel Moise.

On 8 July 2021, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, police officers arrested 11 Colombian men suspected to have been involved in the killing of President Jovenel Moise. The men broke into the Taiwan embassy to hide. The officers of the embassy discovered the men and alerted the police officers who arrived to arrest the suspects.

On 11 July 2021, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, the police announced the arrest of a man who allegedly ordered the death of the President. According to the report, since the killing of President Moise, a total of 23 people have been arrested, including 18 Colombians and five Haitian-Americans. Investigations continue.

Around 21 July 2021 (week of), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, the police arrested three people, including two police officers, allegedly related to the killing of President Jovenel Moise. Investigations continue.

Property destruction: On 23 July 2021, in Quartier Morin, Nord, a store was looted and set on fire. Dozens of residents, accompanied by alleged unidentified and heavily armed gang members, took several appliances from the store. A bank branch adjacent to the store was also vandalized. Sounds of automatic weapons were heard in the area.

On 26 July 2021, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, the police arrested the police officer who was the security coordinator of President Jovenel Moise. The man is suspected of being involved in the killing of President Jovenel Moise. Investigations continue.

Non-violent activity: On 13 August 2021, near Montrouis, Artibonite, armed men blocked National Road 1. The incident would reportedly be linked to a land dispute in the area. Details of the roadblock were not reported.

Security measures: On 14 August 2021, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, Prime Minister Ariel Henry declared state of emergency after the earthquake of magnitude 7.2 on the Richter scale that hit Haiti on the same day.

On 18 August 2021, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, the leaders of the three Martissant gangs, Grand-Ravine, Ti Bwa and Village de Dieu, have agreed to a truce in order to facilitate the delivery of humanitarian aid to the victims of the earthquake of magnitude 7.2 on the Richter scale that hit Haiti on the same week. The gang leaders agreed not to attack the vehicles in the area.
Other: On 2 September 2021, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, a witness reported heavily armed alleged gang members demanding ransom from passers-by in the Drouillard neighbourhood.

Non-violent activity: Around 2 September 2021 (as reported), in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, 400 Mawozo Gang members patrolled the city with megaphones, inviting neighbours not to be afraid of them and saying that the police cannot do anything against their strength. This action follows clashes between rival gangs and police officers in the Croix-des-Bouquets district recorded during the week.

Non-violent activity: On 2 September 2021, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, unknown gang members blocked roads and set barricades of flaming tires at La Saline neighbourhood. The incident is believed to be an act of gangs to intimidate residents and defy the police.

Non-violent activity: On 6 September 2021, near Port-au-Prince, Ouest, alleged G-9 Gang members blocked with trucks, containers, barricades and flaming tires several roads and neighbourhoods of the city, including the surroundings of the international airport. According to eyewitnesses, gunshots were heard and heavily armed alleged gang members have been seen in the streets.
Non-violent activity: On 13 September 2021, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, armed men blocked the National Road 2 near Fontamara neighbourhood. Details of the roadblock were not reported.

Non-violent activity: On 20 September 2021, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, the leader of the 400 Mawozo Gang issued an 'ultimatum' to residents to stop all activities in the city. The action was taken in response to a police operation that took place in the area days before (coded separately) and was communicated through a voice note on social media. Residents reportedly respected the 'ultimatum' as several streets were reported to be empty.
Property destruction: On 21 September 2021, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, alleged 400 Mawozo Gang members set fire to several vehicles in La Tremblay and Michaud neighbourhoods.

Around 27 September 2021 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, the police arrested three police officers who were chiefs of operations of the National Palace. The officers are under judicial investigation for their alleged participation in the assassination of President Jovenel Moise.
Looting: Around 29 September 2021 (week of), near Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, alleged gang members pursued and stole 3 trucks carrying petroleum products.

Strikes: On 4 October 2021, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, public transport unionists called for a general strike against crime. Several commercial enterprises, including many gas stations, banks, schools, stores and transport were partially paralyzed in the city.
Looting: On 6 October 2021, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, armed men seized an unknown number of trucks carrying petroleum products near the Bicentaire area.

SOURCE: Haiti Standard; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste; Alterpresse
NOTES: On 7 October 2021, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, police officers arrested the leader and two members of the Delmas 95 Gang in Petion-Ville neighbourhood. During the operation, the gang leader tried to pose as a police officer.

Security measures: On 10 October 2021, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, the leader of the Village de Dieu gang announced roadblocks across the neighborhood of Martissant and neraby areas in response to shootings carried out by the police in the area.

Non-violent activity: On 17 October 2021, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, the G9 Gang leader accompanied by heavily armed gang members, using the dress code required during national holidays, staged a parade at the Pont-Rouge. The gang leader laid a traditional wreath in memory of a national hero on the holiday that commemorates his death. The parade took place after members of the G-9 prevented Prime Minister Ariel Henry and his delegation from reaching the place and leading the traditional wreath-laying act by intimidating them with the sound of automatic weapons.

Strikes: On 18 October 2021, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, unionists called for a general strike against crime and against the persistent scarcity of petroleum products on the national market. The streets and stores were reported empty in several department. Several demonstrations were reported throughout the week as part of this strike.

Property destruction: Around 22 October 2021 (week of), in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, an unknown number of armed men opened fire on the vehicle of the magistrate investigating the killing of former President Jovenel Moise. The judge was not in the vehicle at the time of the attack.

Other: Around 26 October 2021 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, alleged members of the Ti Bwa Gang distributed letters asking for contributions from residents to buy ammunition. Young volunteers were reportedly being recruited to join the gang at the same time.

Looting: On 27 October 2021, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, unidentified armed men looted the office of the magistrate investigating the killing of former President Jovenel Moise. There is no information about the thigs or documents that were taken by the perpetrators.
Looting: Around 29 October 2021 (between 29 - 30 October), in Chardonnieres, Sud, armed men looted the drinking water system in the municipality of Chardonnieres.
Looting: On 3 November 2021, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gang members seized 4 trucks transporting fuel in the Martissant neighbourhood.

Non-violent activity: Around 4 November 2021 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, members of the Ti Bwa Gang sent threats to residents of Fontamara, demanding the payment of money for the purchase of ammunition for the gang. The gang also asked a college $ 50,000 (USD) in exchange for their 'safety'.

Non-violent activity: Around 4 November 2021 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, machetes were distributed to Fontamara residents in order to provide them with weapons to defend themselves against 'possible attacks by the Gran Ravin gang'. Those responsible for the distribution of weapons are unknown.
Other: On 9 November 2021, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, heavy gunfire from automatic weapons was heard in the area. No further details were reported.
Other: On 9 November 2021, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, heavy gunfire from automatic weapons was heard in the area. No further details were reported.

Other: On 9 November 2021, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, heavy gunfire from automatic weapons was heard in the area. In the Carrefour Drouillard neighbourhood, armed men set barricades of burning tires for unknown reasons. No further details were reported.

On 12 November 2021, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, the leader of the G-9 Gang announced a 1-week truce, in order to facilitate the distribution of gasoline in gas stations across the country. The truce would be the result of negotiations between a 'commission of notables' from Cite Soleil, members of the G-9 and the government. The measure would be temporary, as recalled by the leader of the gang, who demands the resignation of Prime Minister Ariel Henry.

Around 14 November 2021 (between 14 - 15 November), in Mirebalais, Centre, the police arrested 2 suspected members of the 400 Mawozo Gang during an operation. Two firearms and two vehicles were seized by the police.
Looting: On 18 November 2021, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, armed men seized several freight trucks that were returning from the Malpasse border market.

Other: On 24 November 2021, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, heavy gunshots were heard in downtown Port-au-Prince. The origin of these shots was not specified. The shootings were reported amids demonstrations against increasing cases of kidnapping. Casualties unknown.

Non-violent activity: Around 1 December 2021 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, armed gang members required truck drivers to pay a 'right of way' to cross the area, in order to avoid being kidnapped and looted.

Other: On 1 December 2021, in Port-de-Paix, Nord-Ouest, armed gangs seized the body of a woman (unreported) near the Bassin neighbourhood and demanded money from relatives to deliver the body for the funeral. The woman was a relative of the director of a well-known high school in the city.
Other: On 5 December 2021, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, a gang leader threatened by voice message the citizens not to take the National Road 2 (RN2) in the district of Martissant on 6 December 2021.

Property destruction: On 6 December 2021, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, armed gang members looted and burned the Martissant police station. The property destruction took place amid gang conflicts in the area, although no further details on the event were reported.

On 9 December 2021, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, police arrested 3 suspected gang members, including a local gang leader. The men were accused of murder, theft of motorcycles, ransom, burglary and others.

On 20 January 2018, in Arena Blanca, Yoro, unidentified people attacked the electrical infrastructure and destroyed an electrical mast resulting in a blackout in various parts of the region. It has been one of several similar attacks around that time.

On 24 January 2018, near Campamento, Olancho, unidentified people attacked the electrical infrastructure and destroyed an electrical mast resulting in a blackout in various parts of the region. It has been one of several similar attacks around that time.

On 25 January 2018, in El Junquillo, Olancho, unidentified people attacked the electrical infrastructure and destroyed an electrical mast by burning it resulting in a blackout in various parts of the region. It has been one of similar such attacks around that time.
On 3 February 2018, in Brus Laguna municipality, Gracias a Dios, the police and military seized an airplane that was allegedly used for drug trafficking close to the community Evans.
On 4 February 2018, in the state of Gracias a Dios, the police and military have discovered and destroyed a landing strip used for drug trafficking in the Sikalanca area.

On 12 February 2018, in Brus Laguna municipality, Gracias a Dios, the police and military discovered a plane used for drug trafficking close to the Llanos de Rapa area. On 23 March, it was burned and destroyed by the authorities.
On 21 February 2018, in Choloma municipality, Cortes, the police seized an airplane that was burned and allegedly used the same morning for drug trafficking close to the village Los Caraos.

Around 21 February 2018 (as reported), in San Pedro Sula, Cortes, unidentified people attacked the electrical infrastructure and destroyed an electrical mast in Colonia Santa Isabel resulting in a blackout in various parts of the country. It has been the sixth attack of that kind in 2018.
On 23 February 2018, in Puerto Cortez, Cortes, the Police seized several containers from Venezuela with 1.3 tons of liquid cocaine.

On 28 February 2018, in Brus Laguna municipality, Gracias a Dios, the police seized an airplane that was used for drug trafficking in the area of the Llanos de Warunta. 30 people could escape, but 1 Colombian was arrested with four packages of cocaine and a firearm.

On 3 March 2018, in Choluteca, Choluteca, two men threw a molotov cocktail at two ambulances of the South Regional Hospital. The explosion set the vehicles on fire and both of them were destroyed. No injuries.
On 6 March 2018, in Brus Laguna municipality, Gracias a Dios, the police and military have discovered and destroyed a landing strips used for drug trafficking in the area of the Laguna de Ibans.
On 8 March 2018, in Brus Laguna municipality, Gracias a Dios, the police and military have discovered and destroyed two landing strips used for drug trafficking close to the Laguna de Ibans.
On 10 March 2018, in Brus Laguna municipality, Gracias a Dios, the police and military have discovered and destroyed two landing strips used for drug trafficking close to the Llanos de Samil area.

On 11 March 2018, in San Pedro Sula, Cortes, an unknown number of armed men stopped a bus and forced the driver and all passengers to get off in Barrio Medina. Then, they set the vehicle on fire. No injuries reported. The event is reportedly related to extortion.
On 12 March 2018, in Brus Laguna municipality, Gracias a Dios, the police and military have discovered and destroyed two landing strips used for drug trafficking in the Llanos de Rapa area.
On 16 March 2018, in Tegucigalpa, Police forces of Honduras arrested a serial killer and MS-13 leader. During the arrest the police confiscated police clothes and MS-13 T-shirts.
On 17 March 2018, in Brus Laguna municipality, Gracias a Dios, the police and military have discovered and destroyed two landing strips used for drug trafficking close the Laguna de Rapa.
On 24 March 2018, in Los Rincones, Choluteca, 28 migrants (20 from Eritrea and 8 from Yemen) were arrested and handed over to the National Migration Institute.

On 3 April 2018, in San Pedro Sula, Cortes, unidentified men forced the driver and his assistant to get off the bus. Then, they set the vehicle on fire. This event may be related to extortion. No one was injured.

On 5 April 2018, in San Pedro Sula, Cortes, two alleged members of the Los Chirizos Gang forced all passengers and the driver to get off the bus. Then, they set the vehicle on fire. This event may be related to extortion. No one was injured.

On 5 April 2018, in Tegucigalpa, Francisco Morazan, various men forced all passengers to get off a bus and then set it on fire. Allegedly, the attackers said that it was a punishment for not paying extortion fee to a gang. No one was injured.

On 10 April 2018, in the Department of Olancho, police forces found around 500 hectares of coca and seized 1 small narco lab. According to the authorities, the crops and the lab were associated to unknown Colombian cartels.
On 16 April 2018, in Puerto Cortez, Cortes, the Police seized several containers from Colombia with more than 4 tons of liquids used for the production of LSD and methamphetamines
On 18 April 2018, in the state of Gracias a Dios, the police and military have discovered and destroyed a landing strip used for drug trafficking.

On 5 May 2018, in Lempira, Gracias a Dios, one of the most wanted leaders of B-18 Gang in El Salvador was arrested by the Police Forces of Honduras. The arrested man is going to be handed to the authorities of El Salvador.
On 3 May 2018, in the state of Gracias a Dios, the police and military have discovered and destroyed a landing strip used for drug trafficking in the Llanos de Rampa area.
On 7 May 2018, in Brus Laguna municipality, Gracias a Dios, the police and military have discovered and destroyed two landing strips used for drug trafficking close to the Laguna de Ibans.

On 9 May 2018, in Tegucigalpa, Francisco Morazan, four heavily armed individuals forced the driver and passengers of a moto taxi to get off upon which they set fire to the vehicle. No one was injured.
On 14 May 2018, in the state of Gracias a Dios, the police discovered and destroyed two landing strips used for drug trafficking.
On 19 May 2018, in Brus Laguna municipality, Gracias a Dios, the military discovered and destroyed two landing strips used for drug trafficking in Laguna Rapa and Ibans Sector.
On 30 May 2018, in Brus Laguna municipality, Gracias a Dios, the military discovered and destroyed a landing strips used for drug trafficking in Llanos de Araslaya.
On 12 June 2018, in La Ceiba, Atlantida, the leader of the gang Caballo Loco was arrested.

On 4 July 2018, in Comayagua (Comyagua), National Police officers arrested one of the ten most wanted men in Honduras. The man is member of B-18 Gang and had capture order since 2014. No injured or fatalities were reported

On 18 July 2018, in Brus Laguna, Gracias a Dios, Members of the Inter Institutional Security National Force FUSINA, composed of Police and Military members, found and destroyed two illegal airstrips, presumably used for drug trafficking.

On 18 July 2018, in La Lima, Cortes, one of the founders of MS-13 was arrested. During the arrest the police confiscated a 38mm revolver, a cell phone, 20 doses of crack, 43 doses of cocaine, and 41 bags of marihuana.

On 19 November 2018, in Tegucigalpa, hooded men broke the windows of a restaurant and threw a Molotov cocktail, trying to cause a fire. Nearby the location some students were demonstrating, however it is not clear if this was related.

On 21 November 2018, in Puerto Cortez, Cortes, Police Forces of Honduras confiscated a shipment from the United States of America containing: 12 assault rifles, a shot gun, a pistol, 275 rounds calibre 22, several magazines for pistol. The report does not mention the owners of the shipment.

On 26 November 2018, in Siguatepeque (Comayagua), high profile members of Los Grillos Gang were arrested by officers of Technical agency for criminal investigation. No injured or fatalities were reported.

On 26 November 2018, in Tegucigalpa (Distrito Central, Francisco Morazan), high profile members of Los Grillos Gang were arrested by officers of Technical agency for criminal investigation. No injured or fatalities were reported.

On 26 November 2018, in El Porvenir (Atlantida), high profile members of Los Grillos Gang were arrested by officers of Technical agency for criminal investigation. No injured or fatalities were reported.

On 26 November 2018, in La Ceiba (Atlantida), high profile members of Los Grillos Gang were arrested by officers of Technical agency for criminal investigation. No injured or fatalities were reported.

On 24 December 2018, in Valle de Angeles (Francisco Morazan), one of the 100 most wanted men in Honduras part of the Barrio 18 criminal group was captured by National Police Officers at La Leona Neighborhood. No injured or fatalities were reported.
On 18 Jan 2019, the Police and the military forces took control of some neighborhoods in Tegucigalpa as part of a plan to counter criminal gangs that control illegal activities in the city.

On January 202019, in Brus Laguna, Gracias a Dios department, police officers destroyed a clandestine track. The track has been used for drug trafficking. This is the first track that is destroyed in 2019 in the area.

On January 26 2019, in Brus Laguna, Gracias a Dios department, police officers destroyed a clandestine track. The track of 1,000 meters long and 100 meters wide was used for drug trafficking.This is the second track that is destroyed in 2019 in the area.

On January 28 2019, in Brus Laguna, Gracias a Dios department, police officers destroyed a clandestine track. The track of 800 meters long and 80 meters wide was used for drug trafficking.This is the third track that is destroyed in 2019 in the area.
On January 29 2019, in Olanchito, Yoro, police officers seized 5,000 plants of marijuana. No arrests were made.
On January 30 2019, in Cayo Sierra sector in Tocoa, police officers seized 8,000 plants of marijuana. No arrested were made.
On February 01 2019, in Cayo Sierra sector in Tocoa, police officers seized 15,000 plants of marijuana. No arrested were made.

On February 02 2019, in Brus Laguna, Gracias a Dios department, police officers destroyed a clandestine track. The track of 70 meters long and 20 meters wide was used for drug trafficking. This is the fourth track that is destroyed in 2019 in the area.

On February 04 2019, in Brus Laguna, Gracias a Dios department, police officers destroyed a clandestine track. The track of 800 meters long and 30 meters wide was used for drug trafficking.This is the fifth track that is destroyed in 2019 in the area.

On February 10 2019, in Brus Laguna, Gracias a Dios department, police officers destroyed a clandestine track. The track of 800 meters long and 30 meters wide was used for drug trafficking.This is the 6th track that is destroyed in 2019 in the area.

On February 10 2019, in Villanueva, Cortes, police officers destroyed a drug laboratory. Police officers found barrels of marijuana, guns, and bags to pack drugs. The total amount of the seized drug is unknown. No arrests were made.
On February 11 2019, in Tocoa, Colon, police officers seized 35,000 plants of marijuana. No arrests were made.

On February 20 2019, in the wooded area of El Ocotillo in San Pedro Paula, police officers seized a drug laboratory. Power plants, chainsaws, tools for drug processing, accounting books and devices to control production were also seized. Six members of the Mara Salvatrucha MS-13 were arrested.

On February 24 2019, in the Gracias a Dios department, close to the border with Nicaragua, security forces destroyed a landing track. Security officials reported that in 2018, they destroyed 60 clandestine tracks used by drug traffickers. No arrests were made.

On February 24 2019, in Brus Laguna, Gracias a Dios department, police officers destroyed a clandestine track. The track of 800 meters long and 20 meters wide was used for drug trafficking.This is the 10th track that is destroyed in 2019 in the area.

On March 08 2019, in Brus Laguna, Gracias a Dios department, police officers destroyed a clandestine track. The track has been used for drug trafficking. This is the 11th track that is destroyed in 2019 in the area.
On 15 March, the offices of the Professional Formation Institute in Tegucigalpa were militarized and are now being guarded by Honduran soldiers.
On 15 March, the offices of the Professional Formation Institute in San Pedro Sula were militarized and are now being guarded by Honduran soldiers.

On March 18 2019, in Brus Laguna, Gracias a Dios department, police officers destroyed a clandestine track. The track has been used for drug trafficking. This is the 13th track that is destroyed in 2019 in the area.

On March 20 2019 in Puerto Cortes, Cortes, security forces seized 5,390 gallons of fuel. No arrests were made. However, security forces indicated that members of the Mara Salvatrucha 13 have stolen and sold this type of fuel in the area.

On March 26 2019, in Brus Laguna, Gracias a Dios department, police officers destroyed a clandestine track. The track has been used for drug trafficking. This is the 14th track that is destroyed in 2019 in the area.
On March 28 2019, in Tegucigalpa, police and military officials raided the headquarters of Radio Globo. It is reported that a journalist was arrested. The reasons for the arrest are not reported.
On April 04 2019, in San Martin, Omoa, Cortes, military officials seized 10,000 plants of marijuana, arms, and 5 pounds of marijuana. Three men were arrested.

On May 15 2019, in Brus Laguna, Gracias a Dios department, police officers destroyed a clandestine track. The track of 1,400 meters used for drug trafficking. This is the 18th track that is destroyed in 2019 in the area.

On May 17 2019, in Limon, Colon department, police officers seized and destroyed a laboratory of cocaine, 20 sacs of cocaine, 200 gallons of gasoline, 200 gallons of diesel, and sodium sulphate. The exact number of plants of cocaine that were found was 40,000 plants. No arrests were made.

On May 20 2019, in San Esteban, Olancho, police officers destroyed a plane with Brazilian plates. The plane was used to transport drugs from South America. People, who were inside the plane, escaped. No arrests were made.

On May 21 2019, in Brus Laguna, Gracias a Dios department, police officers destroyed a clandestine track. The track of 10 meters long and 5 meters wide was used for drug trafficking.This is the 20th track that is destroyed in 2019 in the area.
On May 23 2019, somewhere in the Colon department, police officers seized and destroyed 4 hectares of cocaine plants. The exact number of plants is not reported. No arrests were made.

On May 24 2019, somewhere in the Colon department, police officers found a drug laboratory. Coca plants were seized. The exact number of plants is not reported but it is estimated that there are 10,000 plants in the place. No arrests were made.

On 6 June 2019, in San Pedro Sula City (San Pedro Sula, Cortes), unidentified armed actors allegedly torched 20 vehicles of a contractor company of the Energy Company of Honduras in the second circumventing ring of the city.

On June 10 2019, in Brus Laguna, Gracias a Dios department, police officers destroyed a clandestine track. The track of 500 meters long and 15 meters wide was used for drug trafficking. This is the 21st track that is destroyed in 2019 in the area.

On 28 June, 2019, in Tegucigalpa, Military and Police Forces militarized the capital of the country and other locations of Honduras as a preventive measure against the announcement of protests called by leaders of the Liberty and Refoundation (LIBRE) party.

On July 02 2019, in the Cuaca village, Tocoa municipality, Colon, officers of the National Police Anti-Drug Directorate (DPA), the Honduran Naval Force, and the National Directorate of Prevention and Community Security seized 500 plants of marijuana. No arrests were made.

On July 16, 2019, in colonia Toronjal (La Ceiba), the police arrested the boss of the gang called 'Pandilla 18', as well as three other gang members of relevance. Among other things, she was arrested for drug trafficking, impersonating a police officer and gang association.

On July 22 2019, in the Sico sector, Colon department, police officers destroyed a clandestine track. The track of 800 meters long and 10 meters wide was used for drug trafficking. So far this year, 25 clandestine tracks have been destroyed in Colon.

On July 23 2019, in a wooded area called El Merendon, San Pedro Sula, police officers seized 11 guns, 3,200 blisters of cocaine, 500 small bags of marijuana, and 14 cell phones. 11 members of the Mara Salvatrucha M-13 were arrested.
On July 29 2019, in the Brisas del Oro village in Comayagua, police officers seized 500 plants of marijuana and two guns. A person was arrested.
On 4 August 2019, in Bus Laguna, Gracias a Dios, Military Forces of Honduras found and destroyed a clandestine airstrip.
On 4 August 2019, in Tocoa, Colon, Police Forces and Military of Honduras seized a marijuana crop with 16.500 plants and burnt it. No arrests were reported.

On 5 August 2019, in Olanchito, Yoro, Police Forces of Honduras seized 24 properties, five corporations and 20 vehicles owned by Los Cachiros criminal organisation. The properties are located in the cities of Olanchito, Tocoa and San Pedro Sula.

On 5 August 2019, in Tocoa, Colon, Police Forces of Honduras seized 24 properties, five corporations and 20 vehicles owned by Los Cachiros criminal organisation. The properties are located in the cities of Olanchito, Tocoa and San Pedro Sula.

On 5 August 2019, in San Pedro Sula, Cortes, Police Forces of Honduras seized 24 properties, five corporations and 20 vehicles owned by Los Cachiros criminal organisation. The properties are located in the cities of Olanchito, Tocoa and San Pedro Sula.
On 11 August 2019, in Tocoa, Colon, Military Forces of Honduras seizure a crop of around 8,000 marijuana plants.
On 14 August 2019, in Brus Laguna, Gracias a Dios, Military Forces of Honduras seizure and destroyed an illegal airstrip.
On 14 August 2019, in Vallecito, Olancho, three vehicles with heavy armed men were reported patrolling the area and threatening the population.

On 21 August 2019, in San Pedro Sula, Cortes, unidentified men burnt a bus. At least 200 buses remained parked as a demonstration of the drivers, who are scared because the crime is related to extortion.

On 29 August 2019, in Tegucigalpa, Police Forces of Honduras arrested 'Cholo Houston', one of the most important leaders of MS-13 in Honduras. The police confiscated a house full of expensive luxuries and cars, as well as around USD 245,000.
On 29 August 2019, in Danli, El Paraiso, the Transnational Gang Centre (CAT) of the Police Forces of Honduras arrested Norman Amilcar Moncada Sandoval, one of the most wanted men in the country.
On 1 September 2019, in Santa Barbara, Santa Barbara, extortionists burnt the vehicle of a journalist for not paying the amount they asked for.

On 1 September 2019, in Tegucigalpa, Francisco Morazan, a Honduran judge ordered seven environmental defenders and community leaders into pretrial detention (also known as the Guapinol defenders) for denouncing an iron ore mine in a protected area in the municipality of Tocoa in the department of Colon. The activists come from the community of Guapinol and are members of the Municipal Committee for the Defence of Common and Public Goods (CMDBCP) of Tocoa, a network of local communities dedicated to the protection of land and environmental issues.
On 3 September 2019, in San Pedro Sula, Cortes, unidentified men burnt a bus. The perpetrators wrote the word 'tax' in the bus.

On 5 September 2019, in Ilama, Santa Barbara, Police Forces of Honduras confiscated a communications equipment nearby El Pozo Prison. The equipment was used by MS-13 to improve the communications of the prisoners. Five people were arrested, including a technician in communications.
On 6 September 2019, in Jesus de Otoro, Intibuca, Police Forces confiscated a house and other goods owned by the wife of the main manager of MS-13. Her husband was recently arrested.

On 12 September 2019, in Tegucigalpa, Police Forces of Honduras captured Luis Willians Izaguierre alias 'El Poison', number one leader of B-18 gang in Tegucigalpa. The police confiscated a pistol, several boxes of ammunition, a hand grenade, money, some marijuana and a vehicle.

On 12 September 2019, in Choloma, Cortes, Police Forces of Honduras confiscated 37 properties in 34 raids during Operacion Minerva. The operation, against La Banda del Negro criminal organization, included several arrests.

On 16 September 2019, in Tela, Atlantida, garifuna people of Triunfo de La Cruz armed themselves and stated that they will defend their ancestral territory against people that want to take lands in the nature reserve in order to produce palm oil and cattle. They have started patrolling the area.
On 18 September 2019, in Tocoa, Colon, Police forces of Honduras found and seized a plantation of 10,000 marihuana plants. The crop was burned.
On 20 September 2019, in Tegucigalpa, Police Forces of Honduras arrested two B-18 and a MS-13 members. The B-18 members are one of the main leaders of the gang in Honduras.
On 22 September 2019, Police Forces of Honduras confiscated several packs of cocaine valued in USD 20,000,000 in a check point in the road El Triunfo - Choluteca. One Dominican citizen was arrested.

On 23 September 2019, in El Progreso, Yoro, Police forces of Honduras seized properties of the AA Cartel. Five raids were reported in El Progreso and seven in El Paraiso, Copan. Three houses, three commercial companies and 25 vehicles were confiscated in the operation.

On 23 September 2019, in El Paraiso, Copan, Police forces of Honduras seized properties of the AA Cartel. Five raids were reported in El Progreso, Yoro, and seven in El Paraiso. Three houses, three commercial companies and 25 vehicles were confiscated in the operation.

On 24 September 2019, in Tegucigalpa, the Police reported the seizure of five houses, two lots, four Corporations, eight boats and 55 vehicles. The confiscations are part of Operation 'Sky', against an international narco network.

On 27 September 2019, in Tegucigalpa, Police Forces of Honduras arrested the head of B-18 in Tegucigalpa, as well as a woman. The police confiscated four cell phones and two guns, including an Ak-47 assault rifle.
On 28 September 2019, in San Pedro Sula, Cortes, one of the national leaders of Barrio 18 gang was captured in Villas Mackay colony by police forces.
